text: Malt and dark bread smells. Pours a nice brown with a fine white head. Flavors of biscuits and pumpernickel. Medium carbonation and a soft malty finish. Very drinkable and not heavy.

Head is medium sized, beige in color, creamy in consistence and rather quickly disappearing. Beer is clear copper red brown. Aroma is medium intense, very malty, caramel and a bit metallic. Taste is averagely sweet with a low of malt and burnt sugar. Finish is medium intense after sweet caramel and bitter balancing hop with an average long duration. Texture is creamy with a soft carbonation. In overall I miss a certain complexity but this beer is very round, easy to drink and without any flaws. Good one!

F: medium, tan, not long lasting.
C: dark coppery, clear.
A: malt, caramel, toffee, a bit fruity, toast.
T: malt, caramel, light toffee, toast, light to medium body, low to medium carbonation, good one. Sampled from tap @ Salon Piva in Bratislava.

Draught at Ayingers Speis und Trank, Munich. 
Copper, clear body, witha big, fluffy, rocky, lacing, beige head. 
Aroma of caramel, toast, dark berries, bread, cocoa, some grains, some flowers. 
Tastes pretty similar, with some more honey. 
Medium, slick mouthfeel, with a lively carbonation. 
Finishes roasty, a bit dry, a bit sweet, toasty, floral, with grains, some cocoa. 

Nice one. Well balanced, with enough toasty notes, side by side with smooth, sweet notes. Quite light bodied, fresh to drink. Not among my favourite Ayinger beers, but another very good style example.

Bottle shared thanks to sjogro. Clear amber with beige head. Some caramel, brown bread, quite malty, a touch of cocoa. After the malts theres a light grassy and slight metallic finish. Medium sweet and light bitter. Just medium bodied with slight dry feel.
Bottle shared at Maakuns. Pours an amber with an off-white head. Dark malts, caramel, wet bread. Not my thing.

Bottle shared at Maakuns, "Dont take that THT away from me"-tasting. Cola colored, no head. Sweet roasted malts, toffee, chestnut. Moderate sweet and bitter. About medium body, average carbonation. Bittersweet roasty tail.

Tap at Salon piva. Rather amber than dark and the flavours correspond to the colour - only slightly more malty complexity than in the base Hell, with light caramel impression and slightly more body as well. However the beer remains centered on being sessionable, easy drinking. Good.

0,1l from tap at Salon Piva, Bratislava shared with a friend. copper clear color, medium off-white head. smells caramel, spices, peppery, honey. ok smell, a bit heavy on the honey. medium body, soft carbonation, slick mouthfeel. tastes of caramel, spices, peppery, tobacco, ligthly grassy. finishes lightly sweet with notes of caramel, spices and tobacco. okish, does not taste too fresh, but overall still ok and drinkable.

From tap at Salon Piva, Bratislava. Clear dark amber color with a creamy off-white head. The aroma is lightly yeasty (fruity), estery, along with sweet malts (caramel, honey). Medium watery body with a light to medium sweetness and a light bitterness. The flavor is full of plums together with honey, caramel and dried apples.

Color cobrizo, amarronado, translúcido, con capa de espuma de un blanco sucio de tres dedos de grosor (no mucha retención). Carbonatación media. Textura acuosa. Aroma agradable a caramelo y un toque mínimo de malta tostada. Sabor a malta caramelizada, mínimo y muy suave, con toques de fruto seco. No capto mucha malta tostada ni en aroma ni en sabor. Se bebe y refresca, pero no me aporta nada más. Plana de narices.
Color bronce oscuro espuma beige. Sabores cereales tostados algo dulces. Cuerpo fino líquido ligeramente espumoso. Suave y ligero amargo final. Buena.

Bottle pour into shaker pint glass from Cigarette City. Appearance is clear red with slight orange, trace sparkle, two-finger width foamy beige head with fair retention and soapy lacing. Aroma is light fruit, yeast, malts, earth. Taste is European/noble hops, light roasted malt, nuts. Palate is medium bodied with slick texture, lively carbonation and mostly sweet but dry finish. Overall, aroma and taste are muted compared to the usual American beers I have, but still good.
Botella @IXCata Ratebeer Asturias, 10/04/17. BBD:09/17. Color ambarino,corona de espuma blanca, aromas cereal toques tostados, sabor maltosa con notas dulces cuerpo sedoso. Agradable

50cl Bottle @ LaBIRRAtorium, Madrid, Spain.
Dark copper colour with white head.
Aroma is roasted malt, caramel, nuts, toffee.
Taste is roasted malt, sweet, bread, hints of coffee.
Medium body, average carbonation.
Bottle from the Beer Store. Nice reddish brown with foamy head. Medium body, aroma of caramel malt. Lightly roasted malt flavor and brief dry finish.
Avellana, nueces, suave chocolate y ligero café con fondo sulfuroso. Cuerpo maltoso y final seco.
Keg at the beerhall. Pours deep ruby amber, nose is caramel, toffee, wheat, taste is sweet, caramel, toffee, light roasted malts.

Bottle in Seattle. Short creamy tan head. Dark, bright, clear red brown. Nice deep, warm roasted malt. Lovely fruit and tannin. Smooth, round warm malt base, with just a hint of sharpness that cuts through at finish. Fantastic, platonic balance. Nice.

Deep brown/copper color, clean, with a lightly beige compact head. Aroma is caramel, coffee, bread crust. Taste is nutty, caramel, roasted malts. Not too sweet, nice balanced bitterness, dry finish.
Medium body, low carbonation, very easy too drink. Very enjoyable.
Whatever style they make, Ayinger once again revealed to be always between the bests.
This is one of the best dunkels on the market in my opinion.

Ar: Toasted malt, herbal hops; slight oxidation; light bread crust and hay. Ap: Crystal-clear amber-brown; large light tan head with amazing retention, leaves a merengue-like cap of thick foam with beautiful chunks of lacing along the side of the glass. T: Clean bread crust; some light red apple flavor; toasted malt and fresh bread linger in the palate; low bitterness, very little hop flavor, just a bit herbal. P: Medium-light body with medium-high carbonation; finish is dry. O: A clean, toasty German lager; a lot of nice flavors, and a spectacular-looking appearance; could use a bit more malt character to really help it pop, but overall quite drinkable and pleasant.

Poured from a 500 ML bottle into a pint glass at the World of Beer in Pooler, GA. The appearance is a brown colored beer with an orange tint with a large white head. The aroma is sweet malt. The taste follows the nose but with a the additional taste of bread. An excellent beer.

0,5l bottle. Pours crystal clear copper with frothy tan head. Aroma is malt, some roast and caramel notes. Flavor is rich malty, caramel, light dry fruit notes, mild roast and spicy hop finish, mild lingering bitterness. Body is medium texture almost creamy. Light carbonation. Rich malty but still surprisingly drinkable beer.
500 ml bottle pours clean and clear reddish brown with a tan or off white head. Aroma is faint but what I can detect is bready malts. Taste is brown bread, smoked malts, toast. Very good beer.

I poured it from the bottle into a glass. It pours brownish amber with a big, fluffy, beige head and lacing. The aroma is caramel and nuts. The taste is nuts, caramel, bread, and tea. Its very smooth. This was really drinkable and tasty.

11. 12. 2016, Ljubljana, shared with Sanja. Bottled. Nothing out of the extraordinary, an OK choice.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle - the pour is a clear dark brown like weak coffee and a thin beige head. Mild aroma of barley, ripe fruit, nuttiness, tea and hearty bread. Smooth earthy flavors of light roasted grain, fall fruit, toasted bread, watery coffee and nuts.
Хорошее пиво, красивы& цвет, хороший аромат и вкус, непродо& послевк& Годен до 06.2017. (Bottle 0,5/ 5,0%)

Draught. Chestnut brown, tall off-white fluffy head. Average retention. Clean malty aroma. Brown bread, treacle, toasted malts. Light to medium body. Bready flavour. Semi-dry. Nutty malts. Treacle. Dried fruit. Low to light bitterness. Smooth and tasteful. A very nice dunkel

Slightly transparent, lovely dark copper brown , visually beautiful, medium off white head, not much lacing. Aroma is malty, mocha notes. Coffee more noticeable in the taste, fairly sweet. Some caramel.  Mouthful is medium, almost oily, highly carbonated.

Dark brown colour with reddish hints if seen through light. Average white head, decent persistence and some lacing. Mild aroma of dark bread, caramel, dough and maybe a fruity hint. Taste is medium sweet and moderately bitter. Dark bread malts with just a hint of roastiness, caramel, light fruity hints. Finishes with a light and refreshing herbal/grassy note which brings the right balance. Light to medium bodied with light to medium crispness, smooth and clean. Solid and quite enjoyable but definitely not remarkable.
Bottle from Liquor Barn. Pours very dark brown. Aroma is roasted malt and taste is sweet.

Bottle. Brown red woody. Rich malty, bit nutty, caramelly, soft leafy nose. Med bodied, smooth, fresh malty bready flavour. Really like the maltyness here. Soft smooth, nutty bready.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone
Bottle sample at Hy-Vee Oktoberfest. Pours dark brown, off white head. Aroma was caramel, toasty malts, toffee. Taste was sweet, toasted malt, caramel.
Mahogany. Caramel malt aroma and flavour, and a slightly sweet taste with low bitterness. Overall, a good dunkel. Beautifyl color, but not as tasty as I had hoped.
Duft sødlig svag karamel smag sødlig lidt kara blid brød lidt rugbrød en smule vandet

On tap at the Ayinger pub in Munich. Always a bit lighter than I remember these dunkels, this a reddish mahogany rather than a chestnut brown. White foam. Nicely balanced, sweet but not overly toasty malts, balanced nicely, clean. Solid dunkel.

500ml bottle pours out a dark amber topped with a small sand head. Nose is heavy malts pit fruit some and a nice big caramel dough. Taste is more of the nice rich malts dough pit fruit and nutty earth tones.

Aroma; brown malts, dark caramel, grassy leafy hops, floral notes, malted candies, dough, plums n prunes. Look; good beige foam, dark brown red-edged clear body. Taste; dark malts, brown sugar, grassy soft hops, malted candies, chocolate, plum note - leading to a caramel chocolate fruity finish. Feel; nice, smooth, fine carbonation. Overall; making a standard for the dunkels. [50cl.btl 5.0% BB.09.16 #L6011]

August 2016 - Bottle picked up in London and shared on level 42. As Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel. A top 50 dunkel at the time of drinking. Orange brown, hazy, still, foamy tan head. Aroma is bready, musty old toffee, apple. Body is smooth with soft carbonation. Taste is sweet and bready, light toffee, some toast, demerara. Decent dunkel. (3.4)

Tap at Ayinger Bräustüberl. The dark variety of the beautiful Ayinger collection. Still light as a dunkel should be, with some more intense flavours. Nuts, caramel, some liquorice. Balanced, easy, but everything done right. Nice.

Bottle. Mostly clear brown pour with a light tan head. Aroma is sweet caramel and toffee, hints of dark fruit, a little bready. Taste is sweet caramel and light bready malts up front, some dark fruits as well, plum and raisin, hints of coffee. A balanced finish, not too sweet, tasty and drinkable.

Aroma is caramel, sweet malt, bready, metallic, nutty, eh. Appearance is reddish brown, light brown head, clear. Taste is caramel, nutty, a sweetness but also a burned robustness, pretty basic. Mouthfeel is light to medium body, light carbonation, nutty robust aftertaste. Overall, I trust that this is good for the style, but its a fairly easy to drink.

#842Tap. Brown to ruby body, rich beige head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate. Taste is neutral to roasty bitter. Coffee, tones of caramel, roasted malts. Light to medium body, moderately carbonated. Good one.

Draught at Ayingers, Munich. Clear, copper to light brown colored. AROMA- toasted malts, nuts, nougat. FLAVOR- smooth, neutral, lightly bitter, toasted malts, nuts, coffee, some lactic tones. Medium bodied. Good.

On tap at Ayinger Speis und Trank. Aroma is very savoury, almost parmesan-esque. Pour is thick head on top of a dark translucent beer. Flavour is OK, with a little wood leading into the roasted malts. Theres a sharp finish I could do without.

Bottle at level 42, thanks ol dirty D. It pours clear rich red - brown with a medium beige head. The aroma is soft, malt-driven, brown bread, soft fruits, fruit cake, wood and leather. The taste is smooth, toasted brown bread, wood, leather, leaf, light spice, light charred note and a touch of caramel. Finish is dry and leafy. Medium body and soft, foamy carbonation. Decent Dunkel.

$3.59 bottle from Wine Warehouse. Pours a watered-down cola color with a large light brown head. I dd just shoot my nose up with flonaise, so my sense of smell may be off, but Im getting caramels, honey, autumn leaves, light chocolate powder. Flavor is metallic caramel and honey mostly, something in there is burnt. Its OK, but theres also something in there Im not loving. Its the burnt whatever. Burnt sugar?

Bottle shared in London - thanks to Dirty D. Pours totally clear amber-gold with a frothy cap. The nose holds toasted biscuits, light caramel, bread. Medium sweet flavour with lightly toasted bread, more biscuits, toffee. Light bodied with average carbonation. Sweet finish, lightly papery, with more dry toffee, toasty bread. Classic dunky.

Bottle shared on Level 42 15/08/2016. Many thanks to Daniel for this one. Aroma is sweet brown bread., Rye bread, grainy, honey, kvas. A clear orange brown coloured pour with a lasting off white head. Flavour is composed of nutty brown bread, jammy fruits, strawberry, honey malts. . Palate is semi sweet, moderate carbonation. Frothy carbonation. Bready.
bottle. Deep brown with one finger head. Roasty dark bready body. Light dark fruit and some mild cocoa notes. Slightly bitter finish. Very nice.

On tap. Crystal clear brown color with beige head. Aroma has bread crust, dark rye bread and toasted malts. Taste starts sweet and malty with bread crust and burnt sugar. Finish is a bit roasty with a hint of hop bitterness. Medium body with lower bitterness. Really easy drinking yet tasty munchener dunkel.

Clear dark ruby color with thin foam ring. Sweet honey and dates in the nose as well as malty notes. Sugary sweet start with a malty follow up. Minimal roasted notes in an almost creamy carbonation. Sweet and dry aftertaste.

50cl bottle from brewdog online shop. Appearance is light hazy, dark copper. Head is beige. Taste is light to medium sweetness, light bitterness. Aroma is chocolate, roasted, liquorice, light fruit, malt, chestnuts.

0,5l bottle. Pours black with smaal to medium sized white head. Good lively carbonation. Deep aroma of roasted malts with a hint on dark fruits. Medium sweetness with light bitterness. Good and nicely balanced.
Bottled 33cl. Color : clear amber ale with almost no thin head. Nose : cereals. Aromas : yeast, roasted malt. Medium texture, low carbonation.

Bottle from BevMo! in Redwood City, CA. Aroma is toasted malts, dark fruits. Taste is light coffee, roasted malts, sweet nuttiness up front and then moves to a clean, light finish. Awesome dunkel and one of the better German beers Ive had. Ayinger can do no wrong.

Pours clear head with thin tan head that quickly disappears. Nose is sweet and nutty. Aromas are sweet and toasty malts. Average carbonation, light body. Abrupt finish. Boarding and watery.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Brown color with a ight beige head, good retention. Aroma is light nutty with toasted malts. Flavor is slightly sweet and caramelish. Weak beer, I expected more about it...

Dark red brown with medium long lasting beige head. Aroma is dried figs, maybe dates, caramel and syrup. Taste is sweet (but not too sweet) with a little bitterness and very natural carbonation induced sourness. Velvety smooth mouthfeel with dates finish. Overall very nice. Comparable with the doppelbock but less intense, less strong.

Pours dark ruby brown from the bottle. Clear, with a frothy tan head that quickly subsides. Aroma has strong caramel and roasted notes with evident toffee. Taste is bittersweet with rich roasted malt flavors. Lots of toffee. Could be a bit more robust, and no exotic notes here, but is still a pleasant sipping companion and quite good for the style. Good stuff.
Pours a reddish dark brown color with a bubbly white head. Notes of karo syrup, earth, roasted nuts. Kind of watery.
.33l on tap @Harrys. Pours clear ruby red with high head. Aroma is dark malts, grass, some hops. Flavor is bread, dark malts, hint of chocolate. Nice!

Pours a sparkling reddish brown body with a tan disappearing head. Rich aroma of bread, wine, dried plumms, malt, with notes of caramel. Taste starts with plumms, later joined by dark bread, chocolate and caramel. A bit metallic. Finish bittersweet of dark bread. Medium body with a thin (a bit sticky) texture and lively carbonation. Pleasant to drink.
0.5l bottle. Ruby color with tanned head. Aroma is toasted malt, caramel and chocolate. Taste is sweet with caramel notes. Medium body and average carbonation. Overall its nice and tasty Dunkel.

From a half-litre bottle. Pours a medium brown. Light-medium carbonation with minimal head. Toffee biscuit nose. Wet mouth feel, a tad of more toffee, but mild. We Americans try to rip this off with our ambers. (my first true dunkel). Pleasant for lack of better word. a drinkin all day beer if I didnt have to work tomorrow.

Ar- light toast, some caramel, toffee, no hop aroma

Ap- dark reddish brown with a weak off white head

Fl- more complex than the hofbrau, subtle malt sweetness up front, hint of caramel, dark fruits, toast

Mouthfeel, med-light bodied, well carbonated, a touch viscous, nice finish

Ov- while more nuanced than the hofbrau I like it slightly less. It good just doesn't really stand for anything. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Corpo bem carregado no malte. Aroma pronunciado. Notas de café e sabor lembrando chocolate. Muito boa.
Almost sweet smell malty. Dark and nice flavor. Tastes malty. Almost like a rye cracker.
Nera con riflessi brown, schiuma grossolana non abbondante. In aroma tostato, cereali, pane. Corpo medio/basso, alta bevibilita.

I drank this beer tonight in Ayinger. The appearance of this beer is a nice copper-orange-red color with an average foam and carbonation. The taste is dry with a nice note of caramel and malty. It is a good drink.

Pours a dark ruby color with medium off-white head. Nice smell of malts and caramel. 

Medium body with soft carbonation. Taste is mostly malts and caramel, notes of coffee in the aftertaste. Roasted, but only slightly. 

Overall, very good and nicely balanced beer.

Good, though a little too light

Bottle, Brewdog Leicester. Golden brown with an off white head. Toffee and raisins with nutty notes. Boiled sweets. Bready with black tea and lemon. Herbal with a roasted, peppery finish. Not had a traditional German dunkel for ages makes a nice change.

Bottle in Brewdog Clapham. Clear, chestnut brown beer with a white to off-white head. Nose is caramel, boiled sweet, barley sugar, slight rye bread. Taste is fairly dull,. Boiled sweet, caramel, barley sugar sweet, brown bread. Dull and one dimensional.

Bottle at home. Pretty deep amber pour with a high beige head. Aroma of cola, sugar cookies, plums, sherry. Light bodied, musty, dank, dried fruits, oxidized, chocolate. Dries up a bit on the finish. Great Christmasy beer.

Bottle to frozen mug in Chaostheorie Berlin. Big beige foam. A little old, some cardboard, old malt and a wee toasty in the nose, mild malty bitterness in the mouth. Medium body, mild bitter finish. Frozen ceramic mug didnt do good to an old bottle to begin with.
Tanned head, deep brown. Sweet roasted malts, fresh hops. Lovely on Christmas table.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone

On tap at Munich brewpub. A clear ruby reddish deep amber with a resilient, beige-ish white head. Aroma is fruits, copper, minerals. Flavor is red berries, minerals. Finish is somewhat metallic, fruity (cherry, cranberry, strawberry). Lingering metallic, mineral flavor. Medium body, average carbonation.

Its really easy to drink.
Smoothy,lightly body,taste not bad.
Can taste roasted malt

I didn't take any extra notes when I tried this beer for the first time but I'm gonna try it again and update my comments.

Bottle at home. Nice caramel and nutty note, lots of malt, good body. Dark and smokey. Enjoyable.

caramel, bread, chocolate, some very gentle roastiness and coffee. 
hops are not detectable. sensed some bubblegum. black, amber when put in front of a light source, slightly hazy, brown foam, minimal head, good retention. 
light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long malty finish.
Sarà che ultimamente sto diventando più buono, non lo so, ma ho trovata particolarmente soddisfacente questa classica dunkel.

Taste of smokey roasted malt, with some bitter hop.
Dark brown and semi unfiltered.
Roasted grainy nose.
almost full body. smaller head.
Bottle from Alko Atomi. Brown with not much head. Some roasted. Hint of coffee. Round bitterness.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone

Poured from a bottle. Aroma is hints of dark fruit and roasted malt. Starts of with a thick pillowy head that disappears quickly with little lacing. Dark mahogany color with some slight haze. Thin crisp snap with the carbonation and the nutty and coffee tones come through a bit more than the aroma.

Bottle from BottleDog, Edinburgh. Hazy ruby body with a thin off-white head. Low carbonation. Aroma of strawberry, caramel, wood, nuts and tea. Flavour of plum, roasted malt and caramel. Thin to medium body with a slick texture. Light fizz. Sweet and tasty.
After running a marathon, marathon munich beer as it enters wonder! No more efficiently and restore hydration German with authentic Bavarian beer

500 ml bottle at SBWF15. Brown with beige head. Aroma has molasses, rye bread, nutty notes, slightly burnt grain and faint yeast. Taste is medium sweet, malty, sugar, molasses, rye bread, slight dry chocolate, nuts with a long bready sweet finish

$3.50 from New Seasons. Cannery Row Beer Club members had mixed feelings on this one. Cheers!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: rye (bread), grain and cereal malts, a hint of roasted malts. Appearance: clear, dark brown, massive, frothy, beige head. Taste: light sweet. Palate: remains dry sweet, intense malts again, grain, cereals, light caramel, rye again, has something of a kvass, gets a bit bitter in the finish, some roasted malts appearing too. Overall: fantastic Dunkel, great aroma with a wide variety of different grains. Bottle from beermerchants.com, Larkfield.
Drank from a nonic glass poured from a 500ml glass. Pours a beautiful clear dark brown color with a bit of head. Smells nice and malty. Has a wonderful dunkle taste. A good brew!

Bottle from The Beer Shoppe, Yakima.
Aroma: Mollasses, rye bread, (J: "buckwheat honey"), yeast, nutty charred grain. 
Palate: 
Flavor: Moderately sweet rye bread, yeast, mineral, nutty, mollasses. Light bitter grain and slightly burnt coffee and a long finish.
Comment: John commented that it had a buckwheat honey character which I described as sweet rye bread.

Avermelhada madeira, espuma de média formação, pouca retenção. Aroma caramelo, media torrefação, bem ao fundo defumado. Paladar segue o aroma, com um pouco de frutas secas vermelhas, baixo corpo e carbonatação. Aftertaste um pouco aguado, mas de média persistência, novamente frutas secas.
2/10/2007 5:31:36 PM On tap at Brasserie Tresznjewski, Munich. Chocolate brown, nut foam. Malty nose. Prickly slight and smooth. Roasted nut flavour and malt.

Brown-amber color with beige head that quickly turns into a ring. Aroma is dark chocolate, roasted malts, caramel. Taste is again dark chocolate, schwarzbrot, nutty, dry. Pure malts in the finish. Lively carbonation, nearly fizzy. Ayinger just knows how to brew their beers, also the beers I usually am not a fan of.

Marrom escura e avermelhada com média formação de espuma. No aroma notas de café, malte torrado e leve presença de caramelo e chocolate. O sabor evidencia as notas maltadas, também presentes no retrogosto. Final médio com corpo leve.

Dark brown color with nice foamy head. Aroma of sweet malts, caramel with hints of dark chocolate. Sweet malty taste, hints of fruits in finish. Overall a nice Dunkel, maybe a little sweet for my taste
Bottle 0,5 l. Nice dunkel with cocoa aromas, malts but almost too sweet for me. No hops to speak of.
Battle. Pour is dark with a frothy head, aroma is toffee. Taste is toffee, malty. Pleasant
Fantastic, smooth & mellow. The appearance is of a beautiful caramel color, aroma is soft, not overwhelming, flavor is nice and crisp, medium body, and the finish is dry and sweet.

Many thanks for this beer to kevnic2008. Piwo o ladnej i trwalej piance, karmelowym i orzechowym smaku. Rubinowej barwie. Slodowe nieco slodkawe, ale w ramach gatunku jest klasyczne. Ale powiem szczeze ze oczekiwalem czegos powalajacego, a tak nie bylo.

Spina in al brewpub.
Color caramello con bella schiuma.
Bella tostata, pulita, davvero piacevole

Bottle. Pours deep Mahogony with an off-White head. Nice roasted malt character. Sweetness is very light and accompanied by a really delicious bouquet of roast, slightly charred malt. Really dry and delicious.
The roasty maltiness in both the aroma and flavor makes this one of my favorites! A slight residual sweetness lingers nicely, making this a true classic!

Bottle to lager glass. Dark, reddish brown pour with a small but persistent off-white head. Aroma is sweet malt, burnt sugar, some toffee. Flavor hits the burnt sugar even more, with a little chocolate and dried fruit. Really active carbonation. Not my thing.

Aroma is very mettalic, like aluminum foil, with a hint of dark fruit. Very attractive visually, dark ruby with streams of bubbles and a white head. Taste is mostly plumy and date like dark fruit with a mettalic bitterness, the metal detracts from the flavor which would be great without the metal. Palate is fizzy and nice. Overall, better than average, but would be very good without the metal, maybe somthing is wrong with this bottle?
Bottle. Dark ruby purple brown. Not much head or lacing. Very metallic nose. Nice bright, bubbly body. Raisin, slight metal, mild charred malt.
500ml bottle. Dark brown body with a medium white head. Dark sugars, wood, earth, figs, lactose and nuts.

50 cl bottle from monopoly. Dark brown red, clear beer with a light brownish head. Malty to smoky character with some light sweet malt and toffee notes. Not my style, maybe a bit too heavily carbonated.

From bottle, 2-3oz sample, at BJCP study group meeting

Aroma: very rich, malt sweetness, chocolate, very light spicy hop

Appearance: light brown with red tint, light tan head, very clear

Taste: Soft, rich, very bready, malt forward, slight nuttiness with slight chocolate

Palate: medium body, medium carbonation, creamy, dry finish

Overall: A very rich dark lager. Hints of chocolate within a very malt forward and rich taste. Great clarify and body. Aroma is near perfect for style. Great beer.

Dark red-brown colour with a small-medium pillowy beige head. Aromas of roasted malts, bread, nuts, toast and light chocolate, earthy tones develop. Softly carbonated, round and smooth texture, medium-full bodied. Bready-toast malt sweetness up front for a good while leading into a light dry nut bitterness. Medium bit dry finish.
Attractive ruby brown, creamy beige head. Pleasant light roast and smokiness. Cocoa. Bready. Caramel. Nutty. Little dark fruity. Excellent. Im just a sucker for good German beer.
Rich, malt, caramel aroma and taste. Raisin and dark fruit. just really well balanced beer.

Brown with a small beige head. Aroma is bread, caramel, chocolate, roasted malt, some floral notes. Taste is chocolate, caramel, bread, some coffee and roasted malt notes, nice herbal bitterness. Bittersweet aftertaste.
Bottle, 500 ml from Pivoljub, Ljubljana. Pours dark copper with off-white head. Caramel malty, light roasted, bready, sweet, slightly metallic.
Whole grain malt and plum/raisin aroma. Taste is initially mineral water and malts, followed by a sweet raisin/plum finish.

Acobreada,límpida,belo creme marrom com formação de bolhas pequenas e boa manutenção;no aroma malte tostado,caramelo,fermento;sabor segue o aroma,balanceado,doce ser ser enjoativo,final com leve amargor de torrefação,boa carbonatação e "drinkability". Boa Dunkel,gostei,mas uma boa pedida da Ayinger.

Nice clear copper/ brown with some golde hues and a creamy medium lasting beige head. Aroma is nice nuttiness with some coffee notes. Flavor is creamy nuttiness with some light toffee/ caramel notes and a gentle bittersweet aftertaste, fantastic balance. Medium palate, rich and creamy yet still very drinkable. Overall very well rounded, enjoyable and tasty

Pretty mahogany color, nice short head good lace. Nice aroma sweet pastry, dark fruit, raison bread?, vanilla,cherrie leather, nutty, caramel slight spice, chocolate, unique. Tastes picks up what aroma is, smooth creamy, soft malts complex and balanced, slight coffee/ cola. Pretty nice especially for a 5%er. This would be the beer to give someone who thinks they dont like "dark" beer. I cant see anybody not likeing this.
Dark brown with big beige head that fades quickly. Aroma of caramel and grain, a hint of chocolate. Balanced, nearly perfect.

Checking for beers I have yet to tick and found this one. Dark clear amber with a decent beige head. This beer is all about grain. I taste and smell brewers grain and it dominates both. A little chocolate syrup is tasted as is dark fruit. Some caramel, too. Decent stuff.

Surprisingly sweet and malty, Id not had this style, but love this brewery. Pours clear light brown, with off-white head quickly disappearing. Aroma is sweet caramel and malt. Flavor is more of the same, with just a mild balancing bitter. Finishes clean, wanting more.
Bomber into a pint glass. Pours a clear medium brown, with a small white head that quickly fades. Nose is faint aroma of caramel and coffee. Taste is dark roast malt with coffee undertones. Nice.

500 ml bottle. Pours a dark Amber, brownish color with a thick Rocky beige head and nice clinging lace. Rich malty nose is reminiscent of brown butter and toasted grain. Soft sweet toasted malt flavor has a buttery, nutty character. Dry finish. Nice balance and complexity. An outstanding Munich dark lager that is den initiate of the style.

A nice toasty brown lager. Really light body with only faint hints roasted malt and sweet toffee. Perhaps it sat in the fridge for too long because I remember the beer having more character in the past. Nevertheless a decent German dunkel.
Bottle at home from Berlin, 1st May 15. Aroma, some caramel, yeast. Taste is watery caramel, yeast, dark malts. Its quite nice
Cor marrom, brilhante. Baixa carbonatação. Aroma de caramelo com um toque de álcool. Paladar caramelo, torrado e frutas secas, porém levemente aguada......baixo corpo. Retrogosto suave amargor.
500ml bottle from Piligrim. Pours transparent light brown with a small beige head. Aroma is roasted malts and caramel.

Bottle from Beer Store Malvern. Thick roasted malts, oak, chocolate, coffee grinds, plum. Balanced malted goodness. Starts out like a standard dunkel but eventually it becomes pretty obvious this is a special brew.

Dark brown colour with light brown head. Aroma od roasted malted barley plums, with coffee notes. Low carbonation, well balanced bitterness, with sweet fruity finish. For sure one of the best dunkel beers.

I have definitely never had a dunkel this good before. Didnt even know they could be this good. Like the perfect session beer. A hint of roast and nice crisp barley. Pours dark brown with good creamy head and lacing. Crisp and light bitter finish. Wonderful balance and full of flavor. Thick consistency. Near perfect German beer. Bottle.

Tap at the Trank in Munich. Glowing orange-brown, clear. Tall, foamy tanhead. No bubbles. Nose of toffee, a bit burnt, raisins. Very creamy, some vanilla even. Bottle 0.5l at Pivopija NBGD Belgrade Serbia.31.03.2015.Taste with ippopotamo36.Ciao Al! Pour it clear cola color with small white head.On the nose malt,smoke little bit.Taste and aroma of roasted malt but not agressive,some spices,little bit watery end.Not my favorite style.

Bottle at Pivopija beer store in Novi Beograd-Serbia with markoijelena. Pours cola filtered color, small off white head going down fast. Nose: smoked feel, cheese (light), roasted malts. Mouth: high carbonation, malty but a bit too thin. Meh!

500ml bottle into mug. Minneapolis. 

Pours deep brown with amber tint. Quality off white head. Surprisingly transparent. 

Aroma is caramely, toasted malt, prune,brown sugar. 

Taste is quite sweet. Super subtle bitterness in the finish. Still manages to be balanced. 

Body is medium. frothy mouthfeel. Fairly long finish. 

Pretty high quality beer.
Flaska @ NK Ölbaren. Kopparröd klar vätska med halvmörk skumkrona. Lätt karamellig doft med inslag av dadlar. Stram neutral beska med ett diskret bärigt avslut.
Bottle into a glass. Pours a light brown with a tan head. Caramel on the nose. Light, refreshing mouthfeel. Tastes of caramel, toffee, and a hint of ripe dark fruit. Loved it.
UPDATED: JUL 29, 2015 Bittermäinen haju. Vähän savuakin jossain. Vähän löysä, mutta aivan mukava juotava. Tyypillinen illan alku.
Yksi parhaiten onnistuneista maistamistani müncheniläistyylisistä dunkeleista ja henkilökohtainen suosikkini. Mahtava tasapaino.

Chocolate, nutty, grassy, bready grains dominate the nose. Lovely deep mahogany brown/red with thin off-white head. More caramel sweetness comes out in the flavor which is joined by the aroma compounds above as well as an accentuated grainy maltiness. I get a grainy almost grassy flavor on the finish. Maltiness lingers a bit but very clean flavor, smooth, clean finish with perfect balance of bitterness to sweetness. Its proof that beer doesnt have to punch you in the face to be impressive.
From the bottle the pour is dark auburn in color, the aromas are light roasting, vanilla and toffee, taste is Carmel roasted malts, a great dunkle

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2015 500 ml bottle from Cost Plus. Dark, dark brown. Shows signs of clarity with a big, off-white head. Good lacing. Nose of toasty, fruity malt and yeast. Flavors of bread crust and light caramel with hints of dark fruit, plum and touch of raisin. Hops are hardly noticeable, maybe a touch of grassy spiciness. Residual sweetness produces a fairly heavy body feel. Finishes semi-sweet. All in all, an easy drinking lager beer with loads of flavor.
Malty beverage with lots of molasses on the nose. Rather thin body and all in all a little too watery. Drinkable but not entirely successful.
The most overrated beer in the world? Nowhere near to its 100 style rating. Very typical yet quite good and nicely balanced dunkel. Nothing special, good social drink.

Was hieran komplex sein soll, das ist mir nicht ganz bewusst, denn im Grunde spielt das Bier hier nur mit Malz und ein paar Röstaromen. Der Geschmack ist recht langweilig und muffig. Vielleicht kann ein Dunkel eben kein gutes Piwo werden, nicht mal wenn es von den Ayinger Jungs kommt.

Bottle from Getränkemarkt Fristo in Bamberg. The beer has got a deep dark brown colour with an steady low head and medium body. Aroma of malt and bread. Taste of roasted malt, old chocolat, leaves, woods, plums and barley. Malty finish. Solid beer, yet nothing very special or enjoyable.
Strong appiling taste, nice aroma, botle nothing special, but overal a great beer, a choise for every day
** Old rating, 0,5l crown-top-bottle, 2006.  Mild-weiches, karamellig-malziges Bier. Nicht zu viel Herbe spürbar, tief und malzig-würzig. Mittellanger, malzig-leicht süßlicher Nachgeschmack. lecker!

500 ml bottle 
Copper to mahogany colored clear beer with little blonde head. Aroma has herbs, toffee, loafy bread and grass. Flavor has sweet malts, toffee, grass and some dark fruits. Palate is medium full with quite strong carbonation. Finish has medium long bitterness, lasting quite long. Aftertaste has herbs, chocolaty sweetness and malts. A decent dunkel, sweet and herbal.
Vapaaherrantiellä 10/2014. Very enjoyable, balanced and pure German dunkel.

Pours a clear, light brown/dark copper color, topped with a decent tan colored head. A mild malty aroma, some roasty notes and quite some caramel - nice. The taste starts sweet, slightly roasty with nice caramel and chocolate. Some bitterness in the finish. Very drinkable and delicious.
Bottle 50 CL. Pours dark copper reddish with big frothy head. Notes of wood, malts, toffee, slight metallic, caramel, chocolate. Not bad.- beerbasher

On tap at Ayinger braustuberl, Aying. 
Deep ruby color, clear, dark mahogany in distance, big beige head. Quiet nose with roasted malts. Aroma: toasted malts with a chocolatey aftertaste, dark bread, fennel and spices.
Taste is perfectly balanced from an initial mild sweetness to a decisive but not aggressive bitter finish. Body is medium, low carbonation. Finish is dry, medium duration. Excellent dunkel, classic style. "Hell" of a dunkel. 12.8°

"perfect for the style. Ayinger knows what theyre doing and it shows. Nopthing that;ll blow your socks off, but the kind of beer you want to throw back several times during Oktoberfest...or the playoffs!"
A legjobbfajtából való, télen melegít, nyáron hűsít. Tavasszal és ősszel csak oltja a szomjat és ellazít.

Medium brown pour with light tan head and lace. Aroma is light caramel malt, toffee, and breadiness. A touch of earthy hops. Flavor is semi sweet bready malt dominates with a touch of hoppiness on the finish. Meidum bodied with good carbonation. a touch of oxidation?
0,5l Flasche. Dunkles Bier mit heller Schaumkrone. Riecht angenehm nach Röstmalzen. Schmeckt auch so, angenehm süffig.
caramel and fruity aroma with notes of vanilla... the taste of caramel malt and tobacco with some shades of coffee and dark fruits... sweet aftertaste with fruity notes...

On tap at the ABV Public House. Pours a clear dark brown with a small off-white head and some moderate lacing on the glass. Smell is a fruity plum and toffee. Taste is plum and toffee, and a beautiful maltiness. Medium mouthfeel and a hint of hops balances nicely.

Dark chestnut-brown body, large off-white head, soapy lacing. Roasted and toasted malt, with light nut, toffee, and caramel. Medium to light bodied with smooth carbonation and a pleasant semi-sweet character throughout.
Missing Germany in the fall right about now. This one is a perfect example of the classic Munich dunkel lager. Dark and nutty, Clear brown with nice thick velvety head. Yummy stuff!

You want a great example of malt done right? Then look no further than this beer. Wonderful slightly buttery with caramel, toffee and a hint of salt. Rich in malt and absolutely fantastic. What is possibly this beers best characteristic is the very light undercurrent of coffee. Aromas are of buttered raisin toast, I dont know how else to describe it but it is fantastic. Full bodied but not overly so, pleasant. Finish starts sweet but is not at all cloying. Then enters a nice light bitterness and slight crisp bite.Deep mahogany in color with a medium tan head that lasts. This is a great beer, one of the best Ive had in a long time quite honestly. Gotta give it to those Germans sometimes being brilliant in the basics of brewing can lend a more superior product that those seeking the extremes of the craft just to chase down the next "imperial" thing. Great beer.

500ml bottle @ the 8th Shrewsbury Bottle Share, courtesy of blackhaddock down there. Pours dark amber with creamy off-white head. Very nice dunkel with good smooth malts and a nice subtle sweetness. A great example of the style.
Pours dark brown, with moderate head. Smell has some notes of coffe and dried plumbs. Taste is mild, body follows the first sip. A caramel aftertaste. A nice dunkel specimen.

Half-litre bottle: BBD Jan 15. Shared between four at the Sep 2014 Shrewsbury bottle swap. Clear dark mahogany with a full off-white head. Semi-sweet maltiness fills your nose and it tastes also of roasted/toasted malts, some fruit notes also, but mostly and mainly a good malty flavour. Fuller in the body than most Dunkel beers I have had: I really enjoyed this one.

I had this at Global Brew. Pours brown with a off white head. Taste chocolate, fruit, toffee. I thought this was good. I would drink this again.

Hazy dark amber color, small off-white head. Caramel aroma with hints of coffee. Kind of oily. Thin body, average carbonation. Slightly sweet. Not bad at all.

Clear dark brown color with reddish hue, thin tan head. Light to medium body, soft carbonation. Aroma of caramel, chocolate, roasted malt, dark fruits. Very tasty but, unfortunately, watery. Medium sweet taste. Good enough.
Bottle, as pictured. Great beer....chocolate, caramel, toffee. Smooth and silky but not too heavy. Just doesnt get much better than a perfectly made German beer.

500ml bottle from Beers of Europe.Pours clear chestnut brown, short-lived head. Aromas of toffee, light herbal note. Taste is more dark sugars and herbs. Sticky palate, sticky finish. Bit too sweet for me.

While not the most full-bodied beer Ive had, Ayingers Dunkel proved to be very complex and satisfying. With flavors of dark fruit, caramel, chocolate, coffee, and subtle nuttiness, its profile is unusual but very nicely balanced. I also liked the sweet malt smell and just-right level of carbonation. For a beer with 5% ABV, Altbairisch Dunkel offers a lot of flavor and refreshment.

Bottle.

A- Malty, sweet, slightly fruity.

A- Dark amber color, clear liquid, thin head.

T- Malty, slightly roasty, slight fruits, slighly sweet, chocolate.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, malty finish.

O- Not bad, but less than I was expecting. Ayinger produces some good beers but not have been near as rich or complex as I have hoped for. Seemed yet again to be a good beer that is a little watery.

Pours a rusty brown with a medium off white head. Aroma and Taste is sweet mildly roasted malt and grains, some notes of dark plum fruit, light raisin, light bitterness. Palate is a mild crisp mouth feel and carbonation and a medium body. Finish mild roasted dark malt and grains, some caramel, dark fruit plums, ends with mild roasted dark malt and light bitterness. Goes down smooth and easy. A very good and tasty brew.

On tap at McNellies. Pours a clear deep amber with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has lots of bread and grain with a a touch of toffee underlying. Flavor has lots of sweet bread and grain with a bit of toffee and a touch of dark fruits.
Rich malt aroma. Clear mahogany with a very light tan head that lingers. Taste is rich with malt and chocolate. Some slight dark fruit is a nice addition.

Poured from bottle into a pint glass

 Appearance  The beer pours a clear mahogany color with a one finger head just off white foam. The head has a great level of retention, slowly fading to leave a tons of foamy lace on the sides of the glass.

 Smell  The aroma of the beer is quite heavy of caramel and brown sugar with a bit of a roasted malt aroma. Some light chocolate smells as well as some molasses and plum are there as well. Overall the aroma is rather sweet.

 Taste  The taste begins with a lightly roasted and toasted bready flavor with some sweeter notes of a fruity nature with some plum and cherry. As the taste advances, a caramel and molasses sweetness joins the flavor all while some flavors of a light coffee and chocolate come to the tongue. Some more grainy flavors as well as some more roasted flavors come to the tongue after the cocoa and coffee. At the same time, a bit of an earthy and herbal hop come to the tongue, and in the end, mix with the sweeter and roasted flavors nicely to leave a smooth, lightly toasted, and sweeter flavor to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is average in terms of thickness and creaminess with a carbonation level that is on the average side. The average carbonation and body are rather a nice bled for the darker but yet very drinkable nature of the brew.

 Overall  For a dunkel lager this is on the slightly sweeter side, but very drinkable and quite enjoyable. A rather good easy drinking darker lager.

On tap at McNellies OKC. Pours a deep reddish brown with a creamy off-white head. Good lacing that cascades down the glass. Smells of malt, caramel and toffee. Taste follows the nose, along with a bit of toasted grain. Medium mouth thats very smooth. Quite a drinkable dunkel.

16.9 oz. bottle poured into tulip glass. Pours a clear, dark brown with ruby undertones. A medium sized tan head settles into a quarter inch thick with faint lacing.

Smell is of dark roasted malt, mocha, caramel, toffee. 

Taste is heavy on roasted malt up front with notes of toffee and chocolate in the middle and then finishing with mocha and a faint amount of hops. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, smooth, and creamy.

Overall, a great dunkel, Ayinger never disappoints.

500 ml bottle bought at Gorgeous Wine & Cigar in Yuen Long.
Looks: Clear deep amber brown colour; One finger head and light-beige foam which lasts for 1 minute; Very good sticky lacing and fizzy carbonation. 

Aroma: Sweet roasted dark malt, with very fragrant strong caramel, light sticky toffee, sugar, light cream, light coffee, and faint lemony grass hops. 

Taste: Close to light sweet dark malt, with pretty strong roastyness, light nuts, strong caramel, shades of toffee, very light black coffee, light dark chocolate, molasses notes, Cola, light lemon, bitter hops and very sharp grass.

Body: Light. Thin and slightly slick palate. 

Mouth Feel: Dark malt in light body with strong roastyness, but nuttiness is light. Fairly low sweetness, molasses is only notes. Light touch but notable toffee, black coffee and chocolate. Pretty reserved in the malt but hoppy and confident. Yes!

Hoppiness: Faint lemon and grass nose. Expressive lemon and sharp grass in taste. Moderate bitterness to macth the dark roastyness for a quite astringent and malty finish.

After Taste: Quite dry; Roasty and light bitter to mouth.

Comments: This is pretty much my ideal Dunkel should taste like - potent roasty dark malt, nice caramel nose, very low sweetness, driven by good bitter hoppiness and good light touch of coffee, caramel and toffee palate. As a Dunkel, this seems reserved but in a nice way. Smart and very relaxing, Im glad I picked this for the evening. : )

Pours a nice dark reddish brown with a thick head that hangs around. Aroma is huge malt, almost molasses, some caramel, very roasty, and a sweet plum finish. Taste is rich roasty malt, thick molasses, caramel, almost a coffee roast note that is slightly bitter, and a much weaker plum finish than the aroma. Texture is smooth and creamy yet light and drinkable. Fantastic beer, should have grabbed more than one.
0,5l bottle. Pours amber color with biege head. Sweet aroma of plums and porto wine. Sweet taste A bit watery taste.
Dark caramel brown color. Aroma is roasted grain. Taste is sweet, dark roasted malt, a tiny bit of bitterness and a tiny bit of sourness. Im not a fan of the style, but its drinkable and good.

Really interesting style for a dunkel, never had one so refreshing before. Its not as bittery you would expect, has good carbonation and a very smooth finish. Poured a dark clear redish-brown with surprisingly small head. Would definitely recommend!

Well this is one hell of a beer! Of course everything Ive had from this brewery is top-notch so Im not surprised. This one has a very long-lasting creamy, almost tan head that forms lacing on the glass. The color is a slightly light chocolate brown and the aroma reminds me of caramel and a little bit of pumpernickel bagels. At taste, not very bitter at all, goes down sublimely smooth with an average finish that doesnt stay with you for long, which makes you take another sip rather quickly. What I do notice is the exquisitely perfect amount of carbonation. An absolutely beautiful beer!

On top there is a thin creamy off white colored head. It fades down to just a very thin wispy covering that leaves some nice lace rings on the glass as I drink. Its body is a deep brownish amber or caramel color. It has a good transparent appearance and light amber highlights. The aroma has a light sweet caramel or toffee malt character. The flavor has a deep buttery sweet malt with hints of sweet candy, caramel and chocolate. Hop flavor is very mild and offers very little balance. It finishes smooth and sweet with a smooth slick texture. It has a medium body and light carbonation.

Bottle. Pours a clear light brown beer with a quite small off white head on top. Aroma is nutty, earthy and malty. Flavor is medium sweet, big malty caramel base. Rather bland, easy drinking with soft carbonation. Medium short, light sweet finish. Id expected better from this brewery actually.

Dark orange brown pour. Strong tan head. Mild roast and grape aroma, metal, cough drops. Tastes of coffee, soy sauce, slight earth, wood, licorice. some sour milk on the end. Palate of a porter. Dry & full light carb.

500 ml bottle. Pours a clear red brown colour with a medium, long lasting, beige head that laces nicely. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, caramel and a hint of plum. Sweet flavour of roasted malt, caramel and a dry plummy finish. Medium body with a creamy, oily texture and soft carbonation. Very nice and well balanced.

Bottle pours reddish-coffee color with a tan, persistent head. This is worth the more money than, say, a Spaten. Everything I expect from a good Munich Dunkel: Malty, roasty, chocolaty aroma and palate. Overall, everything youre looking for in the style.

Appearance is a clear deep mahogany with a small tan foam cap. Aroma is all malt, with toast, caramel, and dark fruit noticeable. Taste is a clean caramel/Munich malt and toast with a crisp but restrained hop bitterness. Slightest hint of some roast/chocolate malt. Mouthfeel is medium with a crisp carbonation. Finishes malty on the tongue with a subtle hop bit that lingers for a bit.

Bottle in a dimpled mug. Pours dark amber-brown with a short head that quickly dissipates. Clean, sweet malt on the nose and palate. Good carbonation, medium body, sticky-thin texture, and a lightly roasted malty finish. Very German. Very good. Pass the schnitzel please!

Caramel and chocolate aroma with a slight breadyness. Deep copper color with a white head and brilliant clarity. Some chocolate and caramel flavor, an impression of sweetness that does not linger. No hop flavor, malt focused. medium body and carbonation with a slight astringency. Excellent example of the style.
Clear, dark amber. Medium offwhite head. Aroma has malt and caramel. Taste is similar, a little sweetness. Well rounded finish, hint of hops.
Dark red amber, off white head. Raisin bread nose. Flavor is prune, bread crust, hint of roast and brown sugar, and faint red apple.

500mL bottle. Pours a ruddy brown, clear, with a big persistent off-white head. The aroma is sweet maltiness and a little bit of alcohol. The taste is better closer to room temp, where it releases more malty bready flavors. Theres a little bit of raisin in there as well, with a very slight hop flavor in the aftertaste. Good beer, not my favorite dunkel, though.
Brown with very malty aroma. Strong flavors of chocolate. Very tastey beer overall.
Lovin the malts here. Toasty grains. Reminds me of a great breakfast cereal. Well done and recommended.
caramel, chocolate, coffee, banana, medium bitterness, light sweetness, full body, creamy, fizzy,

Bottle. Dark caramel pour with tan head. Caramel malt, banana and sweet ripe fruit in the aroma. Taste is moderately sweet with heavy malts. Medium body and soft carbonation. A bit syrupy sweet. Good, but not a style I gravitate to.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2014 The appearance was a semi-dark brown amber colored body with a two and a half finger white foamy head that lasts about a minute before dieing into the body, foamy clingy lacing starts to spider web after about a minute; light carbonation is seen rising at a moderate pace.
The smell had sweet German malts, light banana, light chocolate.
The taste had a malty sweetness leading to a rich sweet dark aftertaste; sweet dark malty lingering finish.
On the palate, it sat at/about a light to medium in the body as it wants to show a heavier depth to it, but stays lighter to show a pretty good sessionable aspect to it. Carbonation runs really smooth and dark over the mouth and tongue.
Overall, I say this is a wonderful Munich Dunkel that I would have again and wouldnt mind putting it with a piece of cheesecake with nothing on it.

Smooth and easy drinking, not super interesting however. Pours a beautiful ruby red with a thick tan head. Smells of malt and maybe a bit of cherry. Taste is malty, not very creamy, and a slightly roasty finish. Had in the bottle.

Bottle, 0.50l, courtesy of CanCrusher. Clear amber brown color with large creamy light brown head, fair lacing and soft visible carobonation. Another fabulous brew from Ayinger...
Bottle. Pours copper brown with small tan head. Nose is malty caramel, lightly toasted. Taste is sweet malt, molasses, dark fruit, coffee. Im getting a metallic taste.
Has a nutty aroma and flavor with a clear dark caramel brown color. Good foamy persistent head. An excellent dunkel.

I poured a 500ml bottle into a large mug. There was no freshness date.

Appearance: Very dark amber to brown proper hue. Translucent with carbonation visible. Forms a small, off-white, soapy head that mostly evaporates and doesnt lace the glass much.

Smell: Lightly sweet scent of confectionery flavors of toffee and caramel while still giving off a distinct lager aroma.

Taste: I have to admit I didnt have high hopes for Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel. Most German beers are pretty old by the time they reach America and buying one at the beer store is a gamble since many sit there for months on end. Since this isnt a generic pale lager I hoped the distinction would at least make it decent, if not good, but it wound up being very good. I cant believe theres this much flavor in this beer. Its the palate most Oktoberfestbiers are supposed to have but dont - a sweet, smooth flavor caramel and toffee thats not cloying or off-balanced.

You might almost call this an English brown ale in lager form. Plenty of caramel, candied apple, milk chocolate and roasted nuts throughout the palate. A slight increase in bitterness at the peak of the swig, but it quickly reverts back to its sweet malty base. I may even detect some smokiness in here as well. One of the most pleasantly surprising beers Ive had in a long time (thanks to whoever recommended I review it!). 

Drinkability: I compared the taste to that of a brown ale, but Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel also drinks like an ale. The mouthfeel is a bit on the thinner, bubblier side, but nothing spastic. It has a comfortable mouthfeel and a super smooth finish. Its quite refreshing while in the mouth and leaves an almost completely clean aftertaste. At only 5% ABV its extremely efficient for its size and also versatile since it could work in pretty much any scenario involving beer.

500 ml bottle into pilsener glass, no bottle dating.  Pours fairly clear reddish brown color with a nice 1-2 finger fairly dense cream colored head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Aromas of big brown bread, caramel, toast, molasses, chocolate, toffee, biscuit, nuttiness, and light herbal hops.  Damn nice aromas with good strength and balance.  Taste of big brown bread, caramel, toast, biscuit, molasses, chocolate, roast, toffee, nuttiness, and earthy herbal spiciness.  Light earthy spiciness on the finish; with lingering notes of toast, biscuit, caramel, molasses, nuttiness, chocolate, and earthy spiciness on the finish for a short bit.  Fantastic amount of pretty robust flavors; with great balance and complexity.  Medium carbonation and body; with a fairly creamy and crisp mouthfeel that is very nice.  Alcohol is well hidden with hardly any warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is an outstanding Dunkel Lager.  I have never had this style before, but this is nicely robust and complex; and extremely easy to drink.  Very clean for a lager as well.  Such a delicious brew, if only it was more widely available.
Bottle from Alko. Dark red color, white head. Malty, sweet taste with some roastiness, plum and wheat. Very nice dunkel.

Thanks gregwilsonstl! Tasted from a tall bottle into snifter. It poured a beautiful, clear, deep reddish-brown color with weak off-white head. Swirling would kick-up a thin layer of foam each time. Aromas of malt, caramelized brown sugar, rising dough and freshly baked wholegrain bread, toast, light perfumey hops, some faint, vaguely fruity ale yeast esters. Flavors were the same plus some toffee, mollasses, plums, raisins, light nutty and woody tannins, chocolate and coffee. Somehow dry and malty at the same time, rich but smooth. Dark and really delicious. Medium body, bready mouthfeel, nice table strength alcohol percentage.  It struck me as a refined, German-engineered version of an English porter. The only improvement I could think of would be some oatmeal or other unmalted grain for better head retention.
Dark and clear.  A lot of layers and they all work very well together.  Roasty, chocolate, and coffee.  Smooth.  Caramelized and malty.

500ml bottle - $3.29 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours out a clear, dark amber-brown body underneath an inch or two of light beige suds.

Smell: Oven-toasted dark German bread and nuts backed by a light roastiness, strewn leafy hop notes, and a far-off hint of chocolate-covered raisins.

Taste: Toasted dark bread, coffee-laced roasty malts with added tastes of cracked nuts, cocoa powder, and even some dark caramel. Reasonably sweet. Child-sized handful of raisins, faint hint of apple skin. Leafy, herbal hops with enough bitterness to support the sweetness. All the various flavors roll in and around and amongst themselves, everything nicely integrated until the drying, nutty finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Slightly silky on the tongue.

Overall: That dismal dunkel from the 2012 Longshot six-pack was the impetus for this purchase and the difference is night and day.

Ayinger Speis & Trank. Very dark copper/amber body with an off white head. Nice sticky grainy nose. The malty taste is however a bit too light, with very very very light roastiness. Light acidic finish. Eh. A bit of a letdown.

Vom fass @ Ayinger Speis und Trunk, Munich, Germany. Bright and radiant auburn chestnut with a very fine, very tight bead. Mandatory Bavarian crown atop, rocky off-white mess a good inch and a half thick and messy as it ebbs. Smoke, peat, stinging nettles and vine clippings, fresh stripped oak and Bovril layer some hefty chocolate malt notes on the nose, round and generous. Good presence in the mouth, big and rounded body, lightly spritzy in carbonation and long in the swallow. Lots of complex malt flavours; biscuity over cooked brownie front, bitter chocolate, peat and roasted grain in back, light coffee and Bovril blend before a peppery, malty thick finish that is oh so long. Gets better as it warms, a hint of cola beer and smoke joins the medley, smoothing out across the palate. Each sip needs another, it just slips down llike an elixir. Two bottles of it back at the hostel was in order to finish the day off nicely. A very tasty, well made Dunkel. Delicious!

Reviewing from Notes. I had this beer during Oktoberfest 2010 in Munich. An amazing experience. 

Serving type: Served on draft at the Ayinger Haus across from Hoffbrau

A - Bright brown and almost red hues that complemented the base color of a typical lagers. A very cool color that makes you want to look again.

S - Not a whole lot on the nose. Slight sweet, yeast, and bread notes. 

T - Such a clean beer. The Germans do lagers so well and this one is no exception. The darker malts that make up the color and the bigger body also provided a bit more sugar but not overbearing. It was almost like a dark helles.

M - Pretty Good. A bit on the heavier side and a tad viscous but overall it worked well. Not overly carbonated
D - Great. This is a great style as the dark color and subsequent sweetness might appeal to those who are same of the same lagers.

500 mL bottle. Ayinger never seems to disappoint. Theres nothing out of the ordinary here, except for a very well balanced, easy drinking, malty lager. The aroma is rich, hazy, and nutty. A pleasing mix of cookie malts, sweet apples, toffee, raison, earth, and minor leafy noble hops here. On the pour, a thicker, cream head, pillowy lacing and retention, a semi-translucent body, and an amber-mahogany color. The feel is well-carbonated, but also light and of soft-cream, mildly bitter, and neutral balance. Notes of cookie malts, light toffee, cashew, blended mild and dark fruits (again, like apples and raisins), grainy bread, earth, and leafy herb. Overall, this was a solid drink.

500ml bottle.

Pours a deep, clear amber with some reddish hints underneath a small cream-colored head.

The aroma is toasted malts with a hint of chocolate and some other grainy aromas, barley and earthy hops.

Taste is heavier on the hops and has a quick bitter kick up front before the toasted chocolate malts take over.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied and crisp though not nearly as creamy as the marzen.

Overall, its a decent beer, but having just had the Oktoberfest Marzen, I had higher expectations.  This one doesnt measure up to that beer in my estimation.  Still really good for a dunkel.

500ml Bomber, the first ever German beer I have had that gushed.

It pours into my DAB mug a nice perfect brownish red with an off white head that doesnt leave much lacing.

The smell is a bit light for a Munich Dunkel. Im guessing this will fall under the extremely drinkable and not as sweet Munich Dunkel category. It has some Munich malt and some caramel.

The taste is light but good and refreshing. This is a very traditional take at the style. It almost tastes no different than a Helles lager besides a bit less hops and a bit richer malt. It has a subtle nuttiness and roasted character as well.

It isnt the best Dunkel but it is worth a try.

Serving type: bottle
