Pours deep amber with beige head and foamy lacing.  Notes of caramel primarily.  Balanced taste with a sweet finish and a hint of mineral.

Pours clear beer, rufous in colour. Beige head that disappears in short amount of time. Aroma: Grain, fruity, honey. Taste: Sweet, fruity like flavours. Almost medium bodied, a bit sticky. Soft carbonation. Lollipops at finish.

500 ml bottle. Reddish copper color, tan head. Slightly metallic aroma with roasted malts. Lovely smooth flavor with dark malts, milk chocolate and nuts. Lingering malt finish. Medium-full body, medium carbonation. Quality dunkel.
Bottle from Alko. Cola brown beer, off-white head. Sweet malty aroma and caramely malty taste. A bit roasty and creamy. Medium bodied, very well balanced.

Bottle. Dark brown, average and fully diminishing head. Moderate malty and sweetish aroma, dark bread and caramel, light roasted malt. Body is medium, malty and syrupy sweetish flavor, caramel. Finish is average, malty and lightly sweetish, caramel. Caramel sweetish dunkel  nothing special.
Pours a mid-brown with light brown foam. Smells like warm barley. Tastes like wort from a brown/dunkelweizen. (I wonder if the bottle I got was fermented correctly...)

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2015 Pours chocolate brown with a medium head. Aroma is sweet, slightly roasted malts. Flavor is pretty much the same. Decent but boring. (536411)
Re-rate from a bottle @ Zinnkeller. Better than I thought before.

Väriltään tämä sakemanni muistuttaa Coca Colaa. Lähestulkoon valkoista vaahtoa muodostuu melko paljon. Tuoksussa on vihanneksia, makeata mallasta ja humalointia. Maultaan olut on yrttisen humaloitu, hieman paahtunut, hieman katkera ja hieman makeakin. Hiilihappoja on kohtuudella ja suutuntuma on keskirunsas.
Bottled. The color is dark amber, not much head. The aroma is malty with some sweet chocolate tones in it. Enjoyable brew, could perhaps have more body to make it more robust.
Very smooth and clean, proof that German dunkels arent meant to be as harsh as several American Dark Lagers are.

This is an excellent complex Dunkel for contemplation.   A bit sweet for session drinking.  Pours a medium amber/ brown, brilliantly clear.  White head fades quickly.  Aromas of musk and fruit before tasting.  Taste is sweet, almost candy-like, with a somewhat dry finish and aromas of malt and summer fruit followed by a hint of spicy German hops.  Develops a warming alcohol finish, and a peculiar aroma like freshly cut wood.  Very nice.

500 ml bottle.
Pours a slightly transparent reddish brown colour with a small patchy head. Aroma of grainy malts, mild chocolate and not much else. Flavour of dried fruits, nuts and toasted malts. Medium bodied, thin mouthfeel. Lacks character.

Bottle 50 cl. Poured reddish dark brown in colour with light beige head. 
Aroma is sweet malty and some roastiness. Flavour is sweet malty with 
faint tones of spices.

500 ml bottle. Dark reddish brown colour, thin but persistent off-white head. Aroma of sweet roasted malts and dark fruits. The flavour is also roasted, sweetish malty, with chocolate and dark fruits, and a sweet, mildly hoppy finish.

Pours dark amber with a modest head, no lacing.  Begins with barley and caramel, moves into dried fruit and bitter malt, with carbonation moving through to keep it together.  A nicely balanced dunkel.

500ml bottle, thanx to Koelschtrinker!!!
The beer in glass is bright dark red with a medium fine, well-durable head. Smells roasted malty, sweet and pleasant bready. Starts roasty bitter, subtly sweet and bready again. Long sweet aftertaste. The further course is sweet, with nutty notes and hints of caramel and roasted malts!

Poured a dark reddish brown with a foamy off-white head.  Aroma of caramel malts with some yeast and fruit.  Taste has lots of caramel with bread and grains.  Finish is slightly sweet and fruity.  Some nuts as well.  Very good.  This is a great dunkel.
Altbarisch Dunkel, you got Alt in my Dunkel!  Spiced hop bitterness, brown medium bodied, chocolate and biscuit malts.  Make for a good session beer.
Bottle: Poured a deep brown with reddish edges, head was creamy. Aroma was roasted malts with leafiness, Taste was sweet with malt a little fruit and a light hint of grit.

500 ml bottle shared at the Royale by Matt- thanks again!  Pours a clear, dark ruby-amber color with a small off-white head.  Aroma of biscuty, sweet, and Munich malts, straw, crackers, wheat, nuts, and caramel.  Flavor of grass, the same variety of malts as the nose, toast, and sugar.  Light-medium bodied, with moderate carbonation and a dry, malty mouthfeel and dry finish.  Classic example of the style.

This one was in a hurry to get out of the bottle. Quick pour resulted in a beautiful rubyish brown clear beer with huge tanne. d head leaving nice lacing. Such a lovely fresh bread, caramel, prunes, fruity and roasted malty aroma. Lean chocolate acidy mouthfeel. Flavor is round, a bit thin but still lean, fruity, slightly sweet and hoppy. Really nice. Acidy fruity palate. Finishes with a pleasant tart hoppy, frutiy and peppery aftertaste.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours a clear chestnut with medium beige head that dissapates and thin body.  Aroma is medium malt, pretty good lacing, low carbonation, and nice complexity.  Taste is lightly roasted dark malt and some hazelnut.  Best dunkel lager I have tried.
Beautiful color and wonderful malt aroma with notes of caramel. Hints of chocolate and dark fruit. Slightly thin and maybe a bit old.

500 ml bottle pours a clear chestnut body with a small tan head. Aroma is toffee, caramel, brown sugar and a hint of spicy hops. Medium body seems to be a bit overcarbonated. Taste mirrors aroma, with baked brown bread, toffee, caramel, brown sugar, and some nuttiness. Just a hint of spicy hops for balance. A very tasty dark German lager that is quite sessionable.
Eh...underwhelming, overcaramelized, watery Dunkel with some good palate complexity...have definitely had better

Bottle. Low fluffy off-white quickly disappearing head. Clear red brown body. Sweet berries caramel aroma. Heavily carbonated roasted barley malt flavor with notes of nhuts and caramel and a fair amount of hops bitterness. Long bitter sweet aftertaste.

500ml bottle. Pours a deep amber with tan head that lasts and leaves good lace. Very chocolatey roast on the nose. The chocolate is toned way down on the palate with a more typical malty/wheaty feel. A little disappointing.

500 ml bottle.  Pours clear, dark amber with a lasting, foamy, off white head.  Toasted malt aroma with a hint of grassy hops.  Medium, creamy, smooth body.  Flavor of grain, toasted malt, spicy hops with hints of toffee. Long, dry, spicy finish.

very clear but brown/almost red amber in colour with good beige coloured head. very nutty and roasted malts on the aroma as well as caramel and sweet brown sugar. There is some fruity prunes or raisin in there as well. the taste is similar in flavour just with a medium body and with a drying coffee note in the finish. very light in body but quick full of flavour.

Pours a clear chocolate with medium slightly creamy head and medium lace. Aroma is of sweet roasted malts and light notes of fruit and coffee. Taste is a nice light sweetness balanced by darker malt notes and mild bitterness. Smooth drinking and as crisp as it is clear, yet quite a satisfying light body. Quite nice actually, very enjoyable.
Cloudy amber with a large beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, caramel and hints of hops. Sweet flavour with roasted malt, caramel, hops and caramel notes. Slightly grassy. Not bad.

Appearance:  gorgeous amber with ruby highlights, huge fluffy off-white head that lasts forever; beautiful extensive lacing.  Aroma:  sweet and toasty malts, some chocolate and honey; almost like a Toblerone!  Taste: roasted nuts and barley, with a hint of honey; almost like a loaf of dark toasted bread with honey butter.  Finish:  clean and crisp, with the toasted and slightly sweet malts giving way to the barest hint of hops; just enough to pave the way for the next sip.  Notes:  An absolutely beautiful-looking brew; very smooth and creamy, with just a hint of bitterness and enough carbonation to make it refreshingly session-worthy.  For me, this is a great pre-Oktoberfest fall lager.
UPDATED: NOV 4, 2016 My favorite dunkel so far I think.  Warm and rich. Bit of coffee and bit of roasty-ness. Yummy. Serving: Bottle
Amber with a small off-white head. Malty aroma of bread and caramel with a hint of fruit. Sweetish malty and toffee flavour

Dark brown pour with coppery highlights in the light, white head.  Aroma is nuttiness, toffee, mild roast and coffee.    Moderately light body with more roast and nuttiness, coffee, a little chalkiness.  This is a straightforward, clean tasting dunkel.

Pours a reddish brown with tanhead.  Aroma is toasty, caramel and doug.  Taste is sweet with a roasty coffee finish.  Not to dark and not to light, a fantastic dunkel.  Very smooth and easy to drink, nice session.

Malty, prune, roasty aroma. Dark brown with a bit of orange. Crystal clear with a medium light tan head. Flavor is strong malty.... dark fruits, plum, raisin, prune..... chocolate and coffee, but not heavy. Even with all these normally strong flavors, this beer remains mellow and smooth, not heavy. You could easily enjoy this beer by the liter. Palate is medium body and crisp. Overall... this beer is marvelous. It defines the style as far as I am concerned. A must try.
Reddish brown color with a thin slightly off-white head.  Aroma of nuts, roasted malts, and dark fruit.  Tastes of roasted malt, coffee, sweetened by chocolate and by dark fruit.

500 ml. bottle- Pours dark ruby red with a nice 1 finger off white head, nice decorative lacework. Aroma is strong caramel malt and rye, not a huge fan of rye. The flavor is caramel malts and doughy rye, strong solid flavored beer, rye just isnt my thing. Smooth creamy texture in the palate. Good carbonation, I understand why Ayinger is considered one of Germanys best breweries. As the beer warmed up it opened up some interesting flavors of brown sugar, almonds and plums (upped my taste score from 7 to 8, and almost no bitterness.

Bottle: Medium Brown coloration with a mild head, , with a vague nutty, dough aroma. Flavors are dough and roasted caramel malt. Not a fan of dunkels after trying this one. I tried to enjoy it for what it is - but it doesnt work for me at all.
Dark brown pour with a red tint. Taste of coffee and chocolate malt. First beer I have tried in this style and was definitely not let down!

Bottle from Kenny Road Market, poured into mug. Pours a clear brown color with an appealing beige head. Ayinger certainly knows how to make a good looking beer. Aroma is sweet, full of toffee, nuts, and malt. Flavor contains notes of dark fruit along with the elements carried over from the aroma. Good stuff.

Dark copper pour, no head or lace. Sweet caramel aroma. Thick and phlegmy. A bit sour with an unpleasant caramel, brown sugar flavor. A little on the flat side, may be oxidized. Par for a dunkel, but may be a little old.

50cl bottle. Pours a clear reddish amber with a beige head. Good lacing foam. Strong malty aroma with toffee and roasted notes. Taste is malty again with notes of caramel. Light bitterness. Well balanced beer, with medium carbonation and dry mouthfeel.

Bottle via Spirits Red Bank. Poured a chocolate brown body with orange higlights on the edges with an average to large sized creamy off white/light beige head. Aromas of chocolate/earth/toffee. The body on this one is just so full and creamy that on a hot day in the arking lot tailgating for the Blueclaws game it was just a bit too much. Flavors of chocolate, earth, toffee, grass and prunes. Solid beer but just a bit to full and creamy on a warm day but probably awesome in Oct/Nov.

Served in a tulip from the bottle.  This ones a very clear brown with ruby highlights and thick two inch slightly tan-tinted white head with fairly good persistence and little lacing.  Immediate aroma is heavily dark chocolate, though this dissipates quickly as more toasty-sweet malt nose kicks in.  A very light astringency lingers in the background, along with some of that chocolate.  Shes very smooth on the palate, with no detectable hop flavor, and a medium bit of bitterness thats most clear on the backend.  Flavor is generally toast and chocolate, the bitterness mellowing out the sweetness and lingering a bit past the finish.  Great brew.
Bottle, pours dark brown. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, nuts, wood and smoke. Flavour of roasted malt, wood and nuts.

(Draught at Ölbaren, Copenhagen, 18 June 2010) Reddish brown colour with frothy, beige head. Malty, toasted nose with notes of caramel, dark fruit and spicy hops. Malty, toasty taste with roasted malt, brown sugar and dried fruit. A solid malt sweetness turns drier in a finish with a spicy bitterness. Medium body. Nice and tasty vienna.

Bottle shared by Thierry and Marc.
Appearance : Clear amber with medium head.

Aroma : Sweet, notes of raisins. Notes of honey and caramel.

Taste : Some oxidation maybe, raisins, sweet dark fruits. Finish slightly bitter with notes of sweet raisins. Some notes of caramel and butterscotch. Finish rather dry.

Overall : Quite drinkable. A bit bland maybe. Not bad but not great.

This is an expertly brewed beer, shows what craftsmen the Germans are as they are restricted by the Reinheitsgebot. Nice thick head, dark reddish color, subtle malt sweetness, very smooth going down. If they could just break the law a wee, add a little bit more body, this would be near perfection.
c.ear amber, small white head. Aromais faint sweet and flowery.6 flavor is nutty, bitter, malty 7 overall an interesting caramelly flowery faint toffee beer6

6th June 2010. RBESG 10 Grand Tasting at the Brasserie 4:20 warehouse. Clear dark amber beer. Not much of a head. Dry soft palate. A little toffee and tea malt. A little tangy orange hop. Competent and very dull.
Pours dark reddish brown with tan head. Aromas of caramel and plums with some toffee. Toasted malt flavor with some breadiness. Medium body with average carbonation.

although i normally prefer the hoppier side of beers more than the malty, this proved to be absolutely delicious simply because of its delivery. you cannot help to want to take a big gulp of this when you pour it into the glass, the color and aroma are exactl;y what a good dunkel should be without any manufactured sweetness or molasses taste to it like alot of either dunkels or bocks, this kept the true flavor of a lager but with the added aroma of well toasted barley. a very enjoyable beer.

Bottle at RBESG Rome Grand Tasting. Dark brown colour, light beige head. Aroma of toffee and burnt sugar, light roasted malts. Flavour is quite sweet, malty, brown sugar, caramel, light cocoa, bit of paper, light bitter finish. Ligth to medium bodied. Expected more of this..

Clear chocolate brown with a cappuccino-colored head that left nice lacing. Toffee aromas up front, with some dark fruit and caramel behind it. Hints of coffee as well. Flavors of chewy toasted bread-like flavor, with the caramel and dark fruit similar to the aroma. Soft, chewy mouthfeel, high carbonation and a bit of a coffee finish.

Botella. Clear deep amber-brown colour with a beige bubbly head, fairly well lasting. Roasty,  dark fruity, burned caramel aroma, mild chocolate. Good mouthfeel. The flavour: roasty caramel, dark bready malt, dark fruit and bit of smoke, pleasant bitterness, dry. Roasty caramel malty bready mild bitter finish.

Bottle shared by plovmand, appreciated.  :-)
It pours a dark amber colour with tan head. 
The aroma is dominated by caramel rock candy and dark fruit. 
Flavour is caramel, light roasted malt, dark fruit and a little hops.
Bottle. Pours dark amber with a small off white head. The aroma is loaded with toasted caramel, light  smoke and dark fruit. Lots of caramel with some dark fruit and light hops.
bottle at RBESG 2010 ... copper ... rich burnt sugers nose ... sweet mlats .. loads of soft roast sugers ... light tofee

Poured from 500ml bottle.  Molasses, malt in aroma.  Looks like cream soda - dark brown solid with tan head.  Butterscotch, caramel, smoke, pumpernickel in flavor.  Creamy feel.  A touch of hop bitterness in back.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Pours a dark, translucent ruby color with a fluffy, 2-finger tan head.  Aroma is dark stewed fruits, some toasted bread, notes of caramel and roast, and some molasses or other dark sugars.  Flavor is more roasty and less sweet than the aroma suggests and grainy with hints of chocolate and maybe even a touch of citrus and a lingering malty finish.  Average in body and slightly more than average carbonation.

Pours a three finger cream head that fades quickly leaving a trace of lace. Nice, clear deep amber color. Medium carbonation and medium bodied. Malty nose. Flavor is caramel with a nice hop backbone, clean finish.  $3.70 for a 5000ml bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, MA.

Bottle at No5.
Red-orange with a beige head. Aroma moderate malty (caramel, roasted, a note ofsmoke). Flavor moderate sweet, llight bitter. Medium body. Fine.
This beer is great looking. Its caramel brown color is extremely inviting. It has a slightly roasted fragrance. It has a great dunkel taste and is a very smooth beer.
Great dark chocolate pour. Nose and taste is roasted barley, sweet malts and resins. Rated 1/16/2000
This is one of my all-time favorites.  Every time i pour a bottle it reminds me of freshly-baked wheat bread.  Malty, sweet but not cloying, this is a fantastic beer.
Draught at ØLbaren. Clear red/brown - offwhite head. Dark bread, nutty, roasted, light hoppy, light sweetness, caramel, dark bread.

[Bottle] Pours a dark brown color with a nice looking tan head. Aroma of grains, molasses and dark malts. Taste is of burnt caramel, brown sugar, light vanilla, grain husks, cocoa and ground coffee beans. Fine carbonation and full, almost oily, in body. Well made and nicely balanced!

Pours a deep amber with creamy beige head, thinning but remaining through finish.  Aroma of dark malts with just a bit of sweetness.  Very well-balanced flavor with the right tough of malt and bitterness in the finish.  A very tasty beer from a top-notch brewery.  Sorry I only had one 500 ml bottle - Cheers!

500 ml. bottle.  Pours a very deep amber brown color with small gray head.  Aroma of dark fruit, like plum, grape, raisin, fig, dark chocolate, licorice.  Tastes pretty much like it smells, first notes of dark fruits with a sort of crisp chocolate bite on the finish, leaves breathe lightly spiced.  Chocolate covered dark fruit.  Surprisingly wheat / yeast not noticeable, medium bodied and pretty refreshing, overall quite good.

pours a reddish/pinky brown with a big bubbly but short-lasting head.  Delightful mix of dry and sweet roasted malts and light floral hoppiness.  Very clean, refreshing taste of multigrain toast.  Tasted just a little metallic.
Wonderful dunkel.

500ml bottle.  Pours a deep amber brown with a decent off white head and some lacing.  Toasted spicy malt aroma with some brown bread and toasted grain and light chocolate.  Great toasted malt flavor, with pumpernickel bread notes, light touch sweet grain, with a long finish that is all clean dry malt.  Medium body, moderate carbonation.

Great ruby chestnut pour with beautiful lasting head.  Malty roasted aromas to smell, cardboard basement almost yeasty staleness to round off on some toffee bending caramel stickyness.  Robust.  Bready and nutty with a touch of an earthy vanilla.  Pretty solid, better when a little colder for a tightening crispness which really gives a form to the brew; when it warms it leaves a little rounded and sloppy.  good with food or for a bbq.

Enjoyed from a 16.9oz bottle in an elongated tulip glass.  The beer pours a medium to slightly dark brown color, with a moderate light tan head.  A beautiful melange of Munich, CaraMunich, and Special "B" malts greet the nose, as do some notes of dark fruit and bread.  The palate is outstanding.  Tremendous complexity in terms of the interplay between the different varieties of malt.  The range of flavors and their relative intensity are amazing for a beer relatively light in alcohol content.  Overall, clearly the archetype of the style.  Outstanding.

Pours a dark ruby red brown color with a short lived off white head.The aroma is of sweet roasty malts and some fruit.The flavor is a mild malty sweetness with some fruity sweetness.The body is light with a smooth finnish.Overall another good brew from Ayinger.
Bottle. Pours with a small white head, bronze body. Aroma of cola, brown sugar and grain. Hay, grainy, brown sugar. Light bubbles.

Draught. Clear, dark brown colour. Small beige head has good durability. The aroma is has lots of dark, bready malts and dark caramel. Raisins and a hint of plums in the finish. A hin of diacetyl. Mellow, slightly sour roastedness with light chocolatiness. The flavor starts dryish but malty, finishing darkish fruity and slight acidic. Medium bodied, smooth palate. Don´t drink too cold.

Pours ruby brown with medium-sized beige head; big aroma of sweet toasted maltiness and milk chocolate with hints of dark fruits; medium body, moderate carbonation; smooth roasted malty flavor with toasted caramel notes and surprising, but pretty pleasant, fruitiness.
Copper brown in color. Medium weighted pour. Nice creamy off white head. Sticky. Banana and bananas foster flavors. Aromas of brown sugar, wheat, banana, grains, toast, yeast. Great dunkel
Clear ruby amber, thick beige head. Aroma of cereal grains and light fruit. Taste is rich roasted malt and smooth fruity caramel. Smooth medium body, soft carbonation, grainy finish.

Pours a golden deep brown with a  foamy tan head. Brown sugar, roasted grains and a slight funk in the aroma. Nice creamy palate. Taste is almost smokey, toasted malt but a quick fade. I can appreciate but not necessarily one Id want again
From a bottle poured dark brown with a fair amount of head.  Nice sweet malty flavor with a quick finish.
Not bad, not good. Raisin-y lightly toasty choco flavors, very light in body, but not that refreshing. Sour.

Bottle.  Pours a clear, cola brown body with an average, beige head that drops down to a nice foamy ring.  Rich caramel and raisiny malt with some light bread crust in the nose.  Flavor is of dark dried fruit and caramel with a touch of toast.  Light-medium body with lively carbonation.  Malt forward with a balanced, fairly clean finish.  Quite tasty.

I enjoyed this Dunkel it poured very dark but still wasnt as viscous as a stoudt or porter. The smell was not as intense as others have rated or as the the description states. Great head on the beer and very nice smooth mouth and palate. Enjoyable beer.

The dark malts DO come through in the smell, but you have to find them unber the huge sweet head that assails your senses. This beer is dark like a mustang is a sports car: it fits the description if you your dad tells you so and you dont know any better ie: your too young or stupid to know any better. You can *almost* read through it, nice head, dissipates quick, decent lacing. Decently dark taste and the HOLY CRAP THIS IS SWEET... its just a bit hard to get past for the colour. Very thin tasting, leaves a sweet malt coating on your toung/throat. Remids me of trying the wert before you add your yeast. I expected more. CO2 assult on the mouth. Not positive.

500 mL bottle pours a rich tobacco brown with some white-gold head into a lager glass.  Aroma of amaretto, toasted malts, biscuity, butterscotch; absolutely love the nose.  Starts with the toasted malt/biscuits which carry throughout.  Nut/amaretto and loads of butterscotch culminate in a sticky sweet finish.  Fluffy mouthfeel with medium carbonation and body.  This was a really unique beer that really surprised me.  Love this brew.

Pours a clear brown with a big frothy head.  Malty aroma with some meatyness and grains (sadly something I touched while drinking this, probably from the sandwhich Im eating, is interacting with the aroma to create the smell of dried dog food).  Semi-sweet, medium dark malt and some light nuttiness prevail in the taste and some very subtle coffee notes.  Much more coffee in the finish.  A warming and filling beer.

Pours a dark red with a very foamy off white head with good retention. Aromas of raisins, roasted malts, caramel, toffee, and plumps/figs. Flavors of figs, roasted malts, slight raisin, light toffee, caramel, and wood. Slightly dry finish much like corked wine.

Aroma is light, with some dark fruit and a bit of grainy astringency.
Taste has quite a bit of sour minerality, backed by a roasty bread-crust malt profile. There is a light herbal hop presence as well.
Palate is medium, with medium-high carbonation.
Ayinger Dunkel has a nice character, and is a bit drier than the maltier examples.

bottle..Clear ruddy brown pour .small wispy off white head, sparse lacing. Aroma of dark bread , roasted malts ,nuts and caramel . Flavor is a moderate malt sweetness with notes of bread , smoke ,chocolate and dark fruit . Touch of bitterness at the finish , also dry . Medium carbonation , medium bodied and well balanced .

(Bottle) Pours a copper-ish reddish brown colour with a creamy off-white head. The aroma holds caramel and bread from the rather wort-like maltiness. Some hops in the background. The flavour is light to medium sweet and light bitter. Metal, dry caramel, light dark bread and light hops. The mouthfeel is clean, maybe too clean, I would have liked a rounder profile. Near medium carbonation. Light after bitterness. Light to medium bitter.

16.9 oz bottle from Market of Choice. Pours a medium brown with some reddish highlights, and has a moderate tan head. Aroma is yeast, caramel, molasses. Flavor is caramel and toffee malt, raisins, chocolate, molasses. Very tasty beer, have yet to not enjoy one from this classic German brewery.

Purchased from a party store in Ann Arbor, MI. Mostly to help me forget Im in Ann Arbor, MI. Hazelnut chocolate color, head a little stingy, smells like caramel, chocolate, and spices. Real nice on a real cold night.

One of my new favs. It pours in a deep chestnut color with a nice white head. Amorma is sweet malt, light toasted bread with hints of nuts. Taste is full bodied with a nice mix of sweet and bitterness. The palate last a nice long time begging you to take another sip.

I havnt had many dunkels, but this beer has gotten me more interested. The aroma is sweet and inviting, and the flavor is moderately sweet and rich and deep while the beer itself is not too heavy, providing for an interesting contrast. The palate is creamy and smooth. There are great notes toast and malt through the finish. Overall quite enjoyable.

Translucent brown with a nice sustained tan head... Aroma is slightly sweet, a touch hoppy, dominated by toffee, chocolate, and bread with a hint of grass... Taste is dominated by chocolate and breads with more grassy hops in the background... Mildly warming, excellent mouthfeel..

500 ml bottle. Pours copper red with a creamy off white head. Aroma is very nutty and roasted malt, caramel and toffee. Toast with molasses. Starts sweet and toasty, again lots of sharp nuttiness with just a bit of dark fruits. Finishes smooth with a bit of an earthy hop character that lingers. Medium body and a soft carbonation. Really good dunkel.
poured clear and brown with big frothy tan head aromas of roasted wheat and hops taste of the same with a little caramel and molasses overall not bad

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2010 Bottle; dark amber/brown color. Malty, caramel aroma. Taste of subtle toffee, coffee and caramel. Better beer than I thought is was going to be. Oct.3 - On Tap at Ayinger; even better on tap ... I really enjoyed this beer even though I was sick during the tour ... highly recommend
UPDATED: NOV 5, 2009 Malty aroma with some caramel. Gorgeous appearance with malty flavor with coffee, fruit, nuts and caramel. Delicious.

Roasty, clean and delicious dunkel.  Ayingers Altbairisch Dunkel pours a bright, clear reddish brown.  The head is creamy and pretty thick for the style.  The aroma is toasty, bready malt.  It smells like molasses on toast.  The flavor adds in a spicy note, but the malt is really the star.  Hopping is light but appropriate for the style, just enough to cut the malt sweetness.  The malt flavor is big and thick for a lager.  Ayinger really packs a lot of good flavor into the 5% abv.  This is a very pleasant, highly quaffable beer, another winner from Ayinger.

Pours a clear dark garnet/amber with a substantial light tan head that provides lacing.  Nutty roasted malt aroma.  Sweet roasted malt flavor along with some molasses and mild hop spiciness.  Very good example of the style.  A simple, but flavorful dunkel thats easy to quaff.

Deep amber brown pour with a subtle and pleasant aroma. Crisp and full bodied flavor of roasted malt that contains bitter and sweet notes all accompanied by a nice carbonation.
Dark brown pour.  Tan head.   Dark dried fruit, caramel, grains and some honey on the nose.  Flavor is yeasty and malty as hell.  Smooth and a touch of sweetness.  Easy drinking here.

Pours a clear dark tawny to walnut color with a medium sized, frothy head. The aroma has a lot of coffee, toffee, some grain, and a touch of dark fruit. The flavor is similar, but with a buttery toffee and dark fruit finish. Medium-light bodied with light carbonation. Complex and drinkable.

Bottle.  Pours deep clear chestnut with pillowy, soft beige head. Nice malt flavor, mild hops.  Malt is caramel, mild soft fruits, sweet chocolate notes, and some creamy goodness.  Very mild smoke/char. Very light palate.  Great sessionable beer.
Sparkling brown,lasting beige head.Light sweet carmel malt, corny nose.More of same in taste, light tinniness
500ml bottle.  Pours deep brown, opaque.  Nice fluffy beige head, leaves lots of lacing.  Mild aroma of roasted malt.  Taste is roasted, slighlty smoky malt.  Very drinkable.

Tap @ beer house in Munich.  Dark garnet body topped with a creamy tan head and little lacing.  Aroma of dark fruits, grains, roasted malt.  Body is medium with creamy carbonation.  Flavor is gentle and balanced with dark fruits (dried), caramel notes, and a lightly roasted backdrop.  Best beer I had in Germany.  Very refined.

From the 500 ml bottle with no noticeable expiration date or lot code.  The pour is a bubbly but attractive amber-brown and a small beige head,  The aroma is of barley malts and caramel or molasses.  The mouthfeel is of medium to heavy texture.  The taste is mainly sweet with malts, coffee, and fresh hops in the background.  This too me is how a Bavarian dark beer should be.
Bottle shared with the Dev Knights - Poured a clean caramel gold, white head with some lacing.  Malt smooth with caramel and light grains.  Flavor is really mild and refreshing, good hot day drinker.

Pours a dark caramel color with a fading off white head. Aromas of German malts, caramel, and grainy cereal. Flavor is similar - mainly malts with a hint of dark fruit. Palate has the typical German tingling on the tongue. Not too bad

Pours a dark transparent red with a small white head. The aroma is malty. Caramel, prunes, honey and grass. The taste is really musty, in an unpleasant way. Tastes like old moldy barley... Pours dark brown from 500ml bottle with a generous hea. Aroma is malt,yeast, and dried plums. Nice mouthfeel, moderate carbonation, and 500ml bottle - Pours dark brown with a big, fluffy head that leaves nice lacing. I smelled malts, yeast, and dark fruit. Pours amber brown with a big creamy tan head.  Aroma is caramel, with hints of dark fruits, roasted malt, and molasses.  Flavor is rich caramel, with hints of roasty coffee, toffee, and plum.

Bottle. Pours a pale brown, with a thinnish head, but passable lacing. Nose is quite sweet; toffee, fruit, spice, malt. Palate is soft, sweet, and malty, but complexity comes from the spice and fruit. More impressive than it first appears. Solid.
Pours dark brown with a tan foamy head. Smells very malty, almost sickly sweet. Tastes not much different.
Poured dark reddish brown, chocolate, lightly roasted malts, little caramel, little dark fruits.
Pours reddish brown nice head. Sweet malty aroma slightly fruity. Not much in the flavour department. Malty sweet, slight chocolate notes. Pretty dull.
Bottle.Dark brownish colour with medium head.Aroma of brown sugar and caramel.Flavor of dried fruits and coffee,nice well balanced with creamy finish.
Cuivrée et limpide, elle offre des arômes de boisé et de malt caramélisé. Saveurs légères et douces de malt et de caramel, légèrement houblonnée. Arrière goût agréable et léger.
Bottle.  Pours a brown body with a tan head.  Sweet toasty malt character, hints of char, coffee, light emphasis on dark fruit skin.  Caramel and toffee.  Nice.

Bottle thanks to Scrizzz into pint glass.  Pours a dark but clear brown with some redish hue to it.  Big seafoamy white head that fades pretty quickly leaving no lace. Nice aroma that reminds me of fall: nuts, earthyness, wood, some vanilla, roasted malt. Flavor is the same with a bit more roastiness (almost bitterness) upfront. A bit of a plumb frutiness in there too.  Medium to light bodied with medium carbonation.  Overall: a nice example of a nice style.
Bottle.  Tart/dry cherry and caramel malt aroma.  Medium brown color with small head.  Lightly creamy chocolate-caramel malt flavor - finishes pretty dry.  A tangy, attenuated dunkel - nice.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 500ml bottle into a Pilsener glass.

Appearance: On top there is a thin creamy off white colored head. It fades down to just a very thin wispy covering that leaves some nice lace rings on the glass as I drink. Its body is a deep brownish amber or caramel color. It has a good transparent appearance and light amber highlights.

The aroma is sweet and chocolaty with caramel, grassy hops, grain husks, fruit, and lightly toasted malt. The appearance is dark amber with an average head. The flavor is like the aroma with a touch of cardboard. The palate is typical for the style. Overall a good but not great beer.

Pouring a frothy tan head of two fingers depth above a VERY dark yet clear amber body, a rather mild aroma of spice and some hops was detected.  The taste was both malty and spiced, along with a mouthfeel that was sadly thin and watery until the last third of the glass when things became more "proper".  Finish was sweet.

500 ml bottle purchased at Lukas in Overland Park, Kansas.  Pour is mostly clear caramel brown, cola, with a two inch tan head that falls fairly quick.  Aroma of sweet caramel toffee malt, toasty bread grain, and some apple fruit sweetness.  There is also a faint roasted background, just a whisper. Palate is medium to thin, highly carbonated.  This is a smooth, drinkable beer, but just a bit too sweet for my liking.

Very complex for a lager. Not a big fan of lagers, but this one might change my mind completely. Doesnt finish clean like a lot of lagers. The coffee lingers on, which is nice. Thus is just a great beer.

Tap @ Aying. Pours cloudy amber with a creamy white head and lacings. Chewy malty. A bit of bread, fruit, grain and lots of caramel. Smooth and full palate. Taste is liquorice, caramel and bread - vaguely roasted. Nice

Nice and roasty. A bit fruity. Oranges and lemons. Caramel too. This is kind of all over the place. I lik eit.

Still does in the glass - that sweet, dry cerealish....cant get around that. Guess I like cat food cause this beer is awsome! A modest head arose then disapeared leaving a closer to tan than white coating. The taste is what makes this beer. Still some dry cat food hanging around (Ive tried all my cats food before, so I guess Im an expert) but its better than average dry hoppy finish, mild malts and slight sourness is what really impresses me. Beautiful reddish brown looks killer in my glass which is quickly getting more and more empty due to endless sips. Creamy dry bitter malty finish. Excellent. Remember - Dry cat food in liquid form. Dont think about that too much or youll start to feel sick.
0.5 liter draft at the Ayinger Restaurant in Munich, Germany. Excellent!

I still remember my very first black lager; what it was, where I bought it, and how much of an eye-opening experience it was for a beer newbie. A dark beer that wasnt a dark beer; she wasn’t heavy, thick, richly complex, and deep with alcohol warmth. Instead, she was light, clean and refreshingly flavorful with a delicate personality which instantly won me over. While I haven’t been able to locate that first dark lager, I instead have before me another fine German example in the form of the Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel. Let the seduction begin.She poured a clear black-brown with deep russet hues glinting in the passing light. A cream-colored thick head tops her off before fading into a thin tribute to her splendor. No lace to speak of, though she does poof up nicely with some teasing swirls. Breaking the surface is a nose rich with bready malts, sweet caramel notes, raisins, dark fruits, and faint citric esters. The initial mouthfeel and body are light and clean with a mild, frothy texture. Soft chewy bread and caramel notes are up to play first while bitter nuts and lemon zest follow a close second. Adding depth and succulence to her palate are dark fruity notes of raisins, black cherries, and plums. Grassy hops make a play for the middle of Ayingers Altbairisch Dunkels palate while a clean finish with only a mild aftertaste concludes her performance. It is a pleasant reminder that while she may be dark in color and richer than a light or golden lager, she is still a lager. Clean and refreshingly quaffable, she is perfectly balanced for the ultimate session beer.For the uninitiated, the idea of a dark lager is practically foreign matter to them and about as believable, much less enjoyable, as an alien abduction. Ayinger is here with their Altbairisch Dunkel to prove all that balderdash wrong with a very simple truth: taste me and you will see that there is nothing to fear. Nay, there is much to love and embrace instead.

500 ml bottle in Paulaner half mas.  Dark brown with lasting head and lace.  Roasted hazelnut aroma.  Roasted malty nutty earthy grassy flavors with clean finish.  Medium body and medium-low carbo.  Nice mouthfeel.  Delicious.  Hard to imagine a better dunkel.

Bottle. A clear, brown beer with a small, beige head. Slightly roasted on the nose, with caramel and a weak note of anise. Sweet flavor with caramel, a touch of salty licorice and some roasted notes. 50cl bottle from Kingdom Liquors (Tampa, FL). Pours a clear dark brownish red with a thick and frothy tan head. Good retention and lacing. Aroma is sweet and malted with notes of chocolate malt balls, caramel, molasses, some hoppiness, and just a faint spiciness. Flavor is smooth and creamy with roasted malt, dark chocolate, some dark ripe fruit, raisins, and some faint spice. Generally medium to full bodied with a pleasant sweet and malty finish.

Very tasty and well-put-together Dunkel. Bottled, enjoyed with the wife at home. Pours a dark reddish-brown with a decent head. Malty nose offers sweet creamy coffee, toffee, caramel, and fruity note like red currant. Mild residual sweetness in flavor with mild bitterness for good balance, plus a refreshing touch of bready sourness. Light- to medium-bodied and thirst-quenching yet shows great character.
Bottle. Golden / red brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is malt, caramel, fruit. Flavour is sweet, caramel, roasted, dry, hop, fruit. Quite nice.

This is just about the best Dunkel I’ve ever had. Dunkel is not a style I am generally all that excited about, but this is just very nice. This looks about like any dark lager, it’s a deep brown with a fluffy white head that has perhaps one of the greatest retentions I have ever seen, I actually drank half of this beer last night at home, left and went to the bar, and when I came back an hour later it was sitting there in the mug with a head still on it! Plenty of lace is left on the glass. The aromas are strongly of sweet roasted malt. The flavor is lightly malty sweet with a very faint roastedness, however there are just a ton of flavors in this coffee, chocolate, and raisin are the first that pop into the head. This has a nice soft palate and is very easy to drink, I had a Budweiser after I drank this and that bud was just harsh in comparison.

Nice designed Bottle 50cl. Pours a red-brown clear brew with a huge dense head. Appearance is amazing, top score here! Roasted malt taste is dominant, but there is no disturbing sweetness. Hops decent, a very balanced brew. Highly recommendable for dark beer lovers.
Bottle. Pours deep amber with a beige head. The aroma is malty sweet with toast and caramel. The flavor is more toasty and less sweet than the aroma. Nice.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2014 17oz bottle-pours a foamy light tan head and copper/amber color.  Aroma is sweet medium malt-caramel/toffee, some hay/wet blanket.  Taste is sweet medium malt-caramel/toffee, some hay/wet blanket, some roasty/cocoa, some fruit, faint earthy hops.  Soft carbonation.  Easy drinking malty beer.

15-Sep-08 (500-ml bottle: Sample bottle from the "local" Merchant du Vin rep) Not that I needed a sample bottle from the importer to know how wonderful this dunkel is, but it serves as a good reinforcement. Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel may well be the best example of the style imported into the United States. Ruby-brown in color with stunning clarity, the beer is capped by an inch of dark-tan head. The nose presents clean, rich aromas of chocolate, dark and toasty malts and a touch of earth along with a slight floral-hop backdrop. Core flavors of toasty, chocolaty and lightly sweet malts abound with that rich, worty, melanoidin profile that’s characteristic of dark German beers. Medium in body and carbonation, clean on the palate. The head settles to a wide ring while leaving a few spots and patches of lace. A classic example of the style, one of the best.10-Nov-05 (500-ml bottle: $2.69 at Windy City in El Cajon, CA) I think Ayinger is one of my favorite German breweries whose beers are imported into the U.S. Chocolaty and toasty malts are dominant in this tasty dunkel, with sweetness and bitterness being pretty mild. The chocolate really takes over in the finish. The nose is less chocolaty than the flavor, showing more of that dark, malty, worty aroma typical of many dark German beers. Medium bodied and pleasantly carbonated. The beer is a pretty medium brown color and is capped by a gorgeous tan head that builds to nearly two inches before gradually settling to a thin, complete and creamy layer. Lacing is left in large patches. Overall, not significantly better than most of the German dunkels I’ve tried, but better nevertheless.

500 mL bottle from Wine Warehouse. Reddish brown pour with a 2-finger head. Big roasted malt aroma with some fruity notes and a slight touch of smoke. Roasted malt taste is slightly grainy with raisin notes throughout. A little thin in the end.
bottle, dark caramel color, good malty nose, flavor is fruity with roasted smoke accents, finish is a bitter caramel but smooth

The only draw back on the first few sips is a mild metallic finish.

Very good for a dunkel. Nicely full bodied, but not overwhelming at all. Dark fruit and malt flavor dominates the taste. Not much else going on. Well balanced and very drinkable. Lightly sweet with a lightly dry finish. I am not a huge fan of the style though.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2009 dark amber pour,light head that dissipates. aromas of cherry, fig, dates, and sweet malt.  Mouthfeel very smooth, roast malt flavor, but flavor is not as full as suggested by the aroma.wonderfully balanced.  smooth and drinkable, a good dunkel.  Not really any catfood detected.

plum colored pour with minimal head. aroma of figs, cherry, licorice, raisins, and malt- very nice, one of my first forays into the dunkel category. tastes sort of like a belgian ale but with a very dry finish- maintains the sweet fruit at the start and through the middle. palate is nice, the dry finish is a very nice twist. very tasty.

500ml bottle pours medium dark brown with a tan head.  Dusty, old, dry nose of stale bread crust and dried Munich malt.  Flavor is just as stale, dusty, dry, and old as the aroma, some toffee and light toasted malts tasted as well, but overall not really winning points, but I fear that this may be too old of a bottle.
Bottle.  Dark reddish brown when held to the light.  Aroma and flavor are mostly sweet malts, chocolate, and caramel.  A classic Dunkel.

Bottle.  Deep burgundy pour with an average head.  Very nice doughy yeast aroma mixed with some malt but the flavor is lacking in my opinion.  Mostly sweet.  Smooth and completely drinkable but doesn’t stand out.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2009 500mL bottle. Pours chestnut colored, capped with a thick tan head. Aroma of sweet malt, caramel, light chocolate and toffee. Flavor is primarily cocoa, with nuts, sweet malt, grain, some caramel, a little smoke, and rye. Creamy mouthfeel, with substantial carbonation. Very quaffable and tasty.

Dark mahogon & brow pour nice whit head some lacing
Light caramels hints of alcohol & sugars hints of grain very bsic reminiscent of a brown ale minus nuttiness
Average pal w/ good carb
Slightly bland for the style good still sweet grains some lightly dry finising notes
Very avgv

Pours a brownish amber color with a tan head. Aroma is of dark fruits, caramel and roasted malts. A very malty flavor with roasted malts, chocolate, and caramel. Theres some dark fruits on the finish as well.

had tasting at 99 bottles in federal way.

brown pour with average head. Very yeasty aroma and similar taste with traces of malts and bitters.
Clear tea-brown, moderate head with decent retention. Sweet breadcrust aroma. Breadcrusts, brown sugar, malty goodness. Really delicious!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
UPDATED: MAY 21, 2009 From bottle.  Pours the color of dark wood with a smallish head.  Aroma of malt, wheat and caramel.  Flavor is fairly mild and caramel sweet, finishing with some chocolate and a surprisingly refreshing hop finish.  I enjoyed this, but found the flavors a bit thin and subdued. 
retried 5/19/09:  Ayinger Altbeirisch Dunkel 5/18/09 (bomber poured into an English pint glass. Color is ruby-brown, clear, with a creamy head.  Aroma of dried fruit, chocolate, and earthiness.  Flavor is a continuation of the aroma:  smoky, peaty initial note, old, with toasted nuts and dried fruits.  Flavors linger with nuttiness.  Palate has a medium mouthfeel, not particularly dry or otherwise.  Leaves mouth a bit clammy though.  Interesting take on a dunkel.) 3.4.

On tap at the corner tavern on Edgewood. Poured a deep brown color with a bid of an auburn tint. Flavor was big wheat and bread. Chewy malt profile was followed nicely by a faint hop bitter finish. Typical and expected yeast aromas as per the style.  Very drinkable.

Dont serve this puppy too cold as it is quite sensitive to cold temps. Full pour yields a medium brown /amberish body with a nice thick tan head that never comes  back after the first mouthing.  Lots of caramel  promises in the nose that will reward the tounge if served at the proper temperature.  Otherwise you will end up with a tinny watery body. When served properly  a slick sweet body will slide about your mouth an linger.
Bottle: pours a dark reddish brown with a thin white head, aroma of malt and roasted barley, taste is toasted malts, just a little sweet, with a smooth finish.  Not bad.

Pours an attractive deep ruddy brown with a decent cream colored head. The nose is roasted malt and caramel. The flavor is more of that, with the toasted malt standing out in a smokey, smooth way. Quite smooth on the palate as well.

Pours a medium brown with a nice off-white head which dissolves quickly into a small but lasting layer of foam with some lacing. Aroma is very bready, reminds me of a good Maibock. Tastes lightly smoky, very bready, lightly toasted with some diacetyl, light nuttiness. Body is creamy but thin, carbonation average. Cant say I really care for this one, but then Ive always had issues with Dunkels. Willing to give anything a try, especially given that Ive enjoyed Ayinger so far, but this one falls flat for me.

Bottle...  Poured deep burgandy with a huge frothy head.  Aroma is great, roasted nuts, tea and plums.  Palate is smooth, with flavors of roasted malt, caramel and a touch of hops for a mild, refreshing bitterness.  Some other chocolate, mild coffee flavors too.  Very hearty.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2008 Speis Und Trank, Munich. Clear ruby with a beige collar. Woody, almondy nut aroma with a hint of beefiness. A faint dusting of coffee and chocolate. Woodsy and thinnish with a very milky, mild-like coffeeish note, and some watery hazelnut/almond in the background. If this was a mild Id mark it down for being too bland. Tasty, but vague.

Roasty,slight chocolate aroma, a gorgeous dark hue, taste was a smooth almost foanmy, dark roast flavor,edged toward sweetness then dried out, flavors were inticingly subdued, which I suppose this style should be. A great session brew
nice bready malt flavor.....very clean finish....pretty sessionable....creamy mouth feel......

(GREMANY) Courtesy of AFI96, thanks Waylo !!! Dark auburn color with a thin tan head. This dunkel has a roasted malt / oatmeal aroma and a slight rum / caramel taste. The finish is sweet but kinda dry. So if you see this one give it a try !!!!

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2009 Poured dark copper with a foamy tan head from a .5L bottle. Smells of brown sugar, oatmeal, and burnt caramel. It has a smooth roasted flavor with some sweet caramel and noble hops taking a backseat. Finishes a bit on the sweet side with some lingering roastedness. A very good dunkel.

Dark amber, white frothy head, spotty lacing. Aroma has a really nice, nutty-toffee malt character, dark frutis in the background. Flavor is mellowed toffee and dark fruit, toasted cereal like character through the middle and finish. Mouthfeel is creamy smooth. Decent overall.

Clear brown body with a medium-sized off-white head. Toffee, raisin nose, with clean yeast and light roast. Flavor is lightly sweet with light, dusty chocolate, some raisins, roast and toffee. Medium body is soft with moderate carbonation.

Poured a nice copper red with a one finger frothy tan head. The aroma was sweet, a bit earthy, lager aroma fo sho, bready, basement earthy aromas. The flavor was lightly sweet, bready, malt dominant, very light hop presence, some raisin (?), basement feel is the best way I can describe it. Nice carbonation and finishes earthy with a very very mild hop bite. Easy drinker.

The color was amber, brown.  The head was creamy, off-white, fizzy.  The aroma was toasty, caramel malt, and light roast.  The flavor was toasty and sweet.  The palate was smooth.  The finish was clean.
Draught at their tap. Clear dark brown colour. Nice, big, lacy, stable, rocky tan head. Good roasted flavour, slightly malty.

Molasses and heavily roasted malt aroma, which approaches that of dog food. Very clear brown, with a thick light tan head. Very malty and kibbly flavor. Probably good with stew, but just a bit too similar to Alpo.

Pretty decent overall, standard fare as far as Dunkels go.  Smells and tastes really fresh, some dark fruits and spice follow through with a slight bit of banana, and some creamy nutty flavors.  Not bad.

500 ml bottle.  Pretty color- dark orange / amber with tiny bubbles slowly making their way to the surface.  Beer is clear, with a fluffy off-white head of foam.  Aroma of raisins and malts- overall light aroma.  Rich mouthfeel, smooth and creamy.  Taste is of heavily roasted malt, with licorice and a definite roasted nuttiness.  Maybe some smoke on the edges?  Finish is light, due to the minimal hop presence.  Flavors are nice, work together.  Surprisingly crisp finish.  Solid overall, I enjoyed.

500ml bottle. pours clear chestnut with off white head. a nice nutty and toasted malt aroma. flavor is the same, very clean malt profile, some floral hop in the finish. flavor falls off pretty short. a well executed dunkel that you could drink a lot of. perhaps the fall would be a good session time for this.

On tap at Ayingers Speis und Trank in Munich.
Dark reddish/brown coloured, medium sized pale beige head. Malty,  chocolate and mild spicy aroma with notes of toffee and smoke. Pleasant sweet dryish finis. Another very tasty beer from Ayinger.

Nice, bright red mahogany with a moderate, but lasting head. The aroma has sweetness and notes of roasted malt. The flavour has a light sweetness, notes of roasted malt, caramel and a light hint of nuts. The finish has a slightly dry citrus note. A nice one!
Toasty and malty and delicious.  Really has a hardy, manly flavor to it.  It doesnt just look dark, it tastes dark.

Bottle, bought @ Ølkonsortiet, Aalborg.
Pours a great dark brown with a big, creamy off white head on top. Aroma is sweet, lots of dough and light caramel. Some rye bread as well. Great mouthfeel, rather creamy. Flavour is mild, malty sweet. Rye, dough, lightly roasted and some slight caramel. A smoky and hoppy bitter finish. A very good dunkel.
Bottle. The best way I can describe this beer is celebrator light. Pours a dark brown color. Smells, like whole wheat dough. Taste, coffee, fruity, pleasant. Really good!!

Poured into an Eichhof bier mug. Clear maroon color, with an off-white head that breaches the rim of the glass. No lacing, decent retention.

Spicy and doughy notes on the nose. Sweet caky malt, with an earthy quality as well.

Flavor is toasty and sweet, with a little fruitiness. Grain, toffee, and a touch of coffee.

Smooth on the palate with good carbonation. You could drink this stuff all day.

pours a nice dark reddish hue with nice off white head, good lacing. Rye bread crust in the nose, also some grainy notes. Slightly sourish rye bready taste. some roasty sweetness. Middle is lacking. Finishes slightly smokey sweet. Good beer.Body is thinnish.
500ml bottle poured into a large lager glass.  AAD pours medium brown with a small head.  The aroma is malty and has caramel.  The flavor is very malty, slightly fruity and soft.

Half liter bottle, for export.  There is a nice, rich head on this brew, and a sweet, tangy aroma that is superb!  Mellow roast grain flavor - toasted bread, with light hop bitterness.  The malt base is pleasant and the finish is clean.  Very drinkable, but the taste is not as fascinating as the aroma and appearance.

500ml brown bottle. Brownish red (chestnut) pour with a big bubbly, foamy tan head. Rings of lacing stick to the glass. Malty aroma with some nut, a hint of roasted malt and mocha. Flavour has some malt depth - medium roasted malt notes, some toffee-like sweetness. End has mild roast/hop bitterness. A little nutty malt aftertaste. Soft bodied with mild carbonation. Probably the best dunkel Ive had. I will be returning to this one often.

Aroma is a roasted caramely scent.  Color is a deep amber with a tall tight head.  Taste is nutty, roasted and lightly sweet.  Starting with a medium body it goes down with a nice smooth, soft feel.  Finish comes in with a mild roasted malt flavor then a light sweet caramel taste and end with a nice bitterness and faint hop flavor.  After taste is a dry caramel taste.  This is a very tasty Dunkel, I would happily have another.
Pours brown, creamy head.  Nose is malty, sweet, maybe some dark fruit.  Flavor is malt, dark fruit, coffee, and a little dustiness.  Maybe my glass was dirty.  Easy drinkin brew.

500. Pours crystal clear very dark brown with a thick, creamy tan head that falls quickly to loose film and sedimentary rings of lace. Nice rich and restrained nose of roast grains, lightly sour, not unlike the coffee the brewer suggests. Rich and creamy but very lightly carbed body, very clean and drinkable. Big nutty, roasty, lightly coffeed mid-palate. Clean finish. Great stuff.
Bottle 0,33l 16 Jun 06. Dark brown /amber colored. A tanned creamy head. Roasted malty aroma. Sweet malty flavor with fruity hints. Roasted dry bitter aftertaste. A good dunkel but a bit too sweet.
Amber of color with a light beige head. An aroma of malt, animal, hay, toffee notes. A flavor of nuts, toffee, caramel, notes of roasted malt and a bitter finish.

Dark red, maybe even brown. Sweet aroma, some roastiness. Flavor is very malty, hints of dark fruit. Very, very smooth, easy to drink without being dull and uninteresting. One of the finer dunkels, and Id expect nothing less from Aying.

(bottle): Pours a dark reddish brown color. Huge foamy, almost creamy off-white head. Good Lacing & somewhat lasting. Dark nutty, clovey aroma. Strong aroma of grape juice. Some smoke. Grape, nutty taste. Watery, wheaty & slightly dirty/dusty. Dark wheaty taste. Easy to drink.

500 ml. bottle. Pours a light brown/red with a strong white foamy head. The aroma is pretty light; some malts and a sweet brown sugar. The taste is really smooth and fairly light; mostly rich malts with some dark fruit, brown sugar and perhaps some coffee. Really easy to drink, but also really good.

One of the most perfect examples of a Dunkle you can find, this is how you brew a complex beer without resulting in a muddled mess.  like the description brags, "malty taste with a hint of plum-fruitiness" delicious!

From a 500ml bottle--poured a rich chestnut amber-brown body with a fluffy beige-tan head.  Robust, sweet, malty nose reminiscent of candy sugar and brown sugar.  Roasted and toasty flavors almost smoky but more like dark chocolate.  Very complex with different flavors coming to light with each taste.  Nice brew!

16oz bottle-A dark amber light brown body with a nice tight off white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, and slight coffee. Taste of this medium bodied brew is of malt, chocolate, caramel, coffee, and finishes with more caramel and a mix of sweetness and dryness. An enjoyable dunkel.

Dark brown. Malty aroma with noticeable molasses. Flavor is quite malty...a bit too much for me, with the molasses still pretty strong. By the end, it was too sweet and syrupy. But Ive been a little burnt out on malty dark beers lately, so Im biased.

Pours a 2.41085285491250 finger head. Chuckle chuckle Any way, huge head, nice red beer with a sweet bread and malt aroma that blends into the exact flavor you would expect from the nose. Very gulp-able.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2009 old ratings:
7/4/7/3/15 - 3.6
7/3/7/3/14 - 3.4

pour is a clear dark copper with a reddish tint, large foamy beige head, above average carbonation, and good lacing.

smell is of malt, grain, some cocoa, some caramel, some fruit, spice, roasted nuts, and bread dough.

taste is somewhat watery, malt, slightly bitter, some cocoa, roasted nuts, touch of prunes, ends a little dry and a little sour.
A very good malty aroma. Flavor is also that of a wooded malt. Very drinkable with a presence of alcohol.  Medium mouthfeel. A nice drink.
Sweet malty aroma.  Flavor was malty and slightly bitter (in a good way).  Sort of light on the palate.. not as heavy a beer as some of these dark beers are.  Refreshing.

Pours 2.5 finger smooth head. Not a big fan of dunkels, bit I must admit this is a very well made beer. Smells like a dunkel (play-doh, dust, and enchilada sauce). Taste is uniform and well-rounded. Clean finish. Silky mouthfeel. Its a very good beer, despite the oddness of dunkels.

500ml bottle. This maybe a biased rating - Not a fan of dunkels, mistook this for a Schwarz upon purchase. This did have an exceptional pour to it.  Somewhat overwhelming malt that is kind of a turn off... surprised this is only 5%. It went pretty bad with my food.  Overall,  It was okay for a Dunk, but nothing i would come back to.

On tap at Winking Lizard: Pours a deep brown with a light tan head. Aroma, raosted notes, caramel, some fruits. Flavor, caramel, and herbal and floral hop flavor, chocolate, some sweet malts, very smooth and quite delicious.

Bottle. Pours a deep brown with a nice off-white, frothy head. Very mild aroma. Flavor is malty with hints of caramel and a little chocolate. Palate is on the light side. Very good overall. Plenty of flavor but very drinkable.

Appearance is clear filtered root beer.  Sweeter malt hard tack candy aroma. Big 17 oz bottle, nice sample size. Taste impact is a malty fizzy beverage, in a good way. No adverse bitterness, but a friendly interesting palate of manure and fertile garden soil fills the mouth with each sip. Very complex. A fine example of a mild dark beer. A hint of 5% is apparent, certainly does not come across alky free. The session ends with dreams of alcohol laced candy while riding a unicorn. Refined, docile and whammy.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
11/01/2007:  Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel has a really nice clear ruby-honey color and a thick and creamy ivory head that is long lasting and creates some good lacing on the glass.  The aroma and flavor are soft and mellow, but packed full of rich caramel malts along with a bit of something darker (like chocolate) and a touch of spice.  It is slightly dry in the middle and has a long, smooth finish.  It is also very balanced overall and just easy to drink.  The palate is smooth, almost silky.  This beer is just interesting enough to hold your attention and coax you into multiple glasses of it!  I enjoyed it and hope to try it out of a bottle sometime...
Draught (16 oz glass) at the Winking Lizard Tavern (Crosswoods) in Columbus, Ohio.  Rating #442 for this beer...
Clear dark brown, practically no head. Little aroma. Not much to say, tastes good, malty, technically well made. And it was a "keep the glass" special @ winking lizard.

Poured a clear dark reddish-copper color with a medium sized beige head.  Sweet and full of caramel and raisins. in the aroma.  The flavor is sweet, malty and toasty.  Clean semi-dry finish.  Light to medium body and a lively mouth feel.

On draught at the Winking Lizard (glass special). This beer pours a pretty burgundy color with a medium thick light beige head that diminishes steadily. Spotty lacing on the glass. Roasted malt, nuts and dark chocolate aroma. Medium-bodied with flavors of roasted malt, toffee and dark fruits with touches of chocolate and hops. The finish is bready malt with a nice lingering roastiness. Overall this is an enjoyable brew, as are the other Ayinger beers I have tried.

on tap. 

brown, fizzy, short lived head. Much better once warmed. Nice blend of sweet fruit and malt flavors with balancing degree of carbonation. Finishes clean, mostly sweet.

Solid Dunkel from Ayinger, of course I was pretty sure it would be since they have yet to let me down. Aroma has a warming buttery, smokey, milk chocolate thing going on with a good bread quality. Dark brown pour with a thick creamy lasting head, and good lacing. Filling and silky to the palate, this drinks with great ease. Very tasty with numerous layers of flavor. Fresh buttered bread and burnt molasses, chocolate malt, red grapes and over ripened bananas. Top notch lager.
6/22/05. 500ml bottle. Mahogany with large tan head. Sweet Malty cookie aroma. Clean sweet malty bready flavor
I prefer way more roast and toast in my dunkels, and although this is supposedly one of the best examples of the style , I found the aroma and flavor to be far too scotchy sweet for my liking.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2010 Tap at Ayinger resturant in Munich on 9-29-07.   The menu called it the "old dark Bavarian".   Dark clear chestnut with tan head.   Bready, yeast, woody, roasty aroma.   Lively carbonation and medium body, but a little thinner than I expected.   Not as sweet and malty as the festbier.   More mellow and full roastiness.   moderate bitter finish.   Not  too impressed. (6,4,6,3,12)Rerate: 50cl bottle.   I can tell that this bottle isnt as good as the krug that I had at the speis und tank in Munich a couple years ago, but I didnt know shit back then.   Pours a beautiful clear brown with a big beige head.   Lot of rich, bready munich malt in the aroma with a touch of mineral.   Very malty, bready flavor with mils hops and just a touch of bitterness.   Medium-light body.   A great dunkel that you cant really fault except for lack of freshness,
Aroma of sweet dark malts, grains, and yeast. Darkish amber color with a small tan head. Smooth flavor that gets sweeter in the finish. Light bodied.

Pours copper with small fizzy head.  Aroma is malts with a little sweetness.  Mouthfeel is a little too carbonated.  Flavor is malts with a little bit of wheat.  Good brew.  Not Ayingers best, though.
Dark and clear.  Aroma of chocolate and roasted malt.  Maybe plums with a strong malt flavor.  I agree with the last rater about metal in the finish, maybe a little salty.

Dark amber pour with ruby highlights.  Big initial light tan head, diminishing to a clumpy film.  Weak aroma of malt, maybe some roast.  High carbonation brings down the drinkability you want in a lager.  Flavor is malt, some dark fruit, with no noticeable hops present.  I also noticed a hint of metal in the aftertaste that lowered my rating of the beer.  I expected more from Ayinger.

Pours dark brown with a impressive tall head.  Smells of milk chocolate and faint bacon.  Thin, watery texture pushes the roasted notes to the sides of the mouth.  Certainly redrinkable, but I was hoping for something with more body and oomph.

Bottle from a great trade with Koelschtrinker (thanks!). A brown beer with a creamy, quite dark, beige head. Malty aroma with roastiness and caramel. Flavor is sweet and malty with bread and caramel. A slightly bitter finish with some smoke notes. Medium-bodied. Good one!

500ml bottle poured into a dimpled mug. Pours a clear reddish brown that is a beautiful ruby when held to the light. A dense creamy beige head diminishes to a thin cap on the surface. The aroma is somewhat muted and is all about the malts: sweet roasted malt with lighter notes of chocolate, nuts, caramel and toffee. Light-bodied and lively with a distinctly metallic finish. The flavor  is similar to the nose with a sweet caramel malt front and notes of chocolate and nuts. One addition to the flavor that was absent in the aroma is a lightly bitter mocha finish. I think that Id like this beer quite a bit if it werent for the metallic quality that I get at the end. Perhaps Im just super sensitive to any hint of "metal" in a beer, but thats the same reason that I dislike most ambers. I pick up that same metallic note in many of them as well.

clear dark burgundy color. light aroma of toffee with hints of raisin. light sticky body with a clean crisp finish. nice roasted caramel malt flavor with a chocolate finish and undertones of dark fruits. easy drinking and very mellow beer

dark, nearly red colour. medium head. sweet and spicy smell. starts soft. then roasted malts. gets sticky on the lips quite fast. mid  brings hops. ends up spicy and sticky. taste is good but the lip-glue also. what a pity.

Bottle. Pours a very deep clear ruby-brown with a large mostly-lasting off-white head. Aroma of caramel malt, slightly roasty, and dark fruit. Delicious flavour of toasty caramel malt, dark fruit, and a lightly bitter, dry chocolaty finish. Medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel. A very nice version of the style and one of the better ones Ive tried, I really enjoyed it.

500ml bottle. Pours a translucent dark brown, with a fading off-white head.Aroma is light with caramel, anise, malts and coffee. Flavor mirrors the aroma with a bit of a sweet syrup thrown in.  The mouthfeel was a bit thin and watery, and the carbonation was very light. Finish was dry, astringent and saccharine sweet. I would have rated this beer significantly higher had the palate not been so weak, and the finish so sweet.

8/8/07 From the bottle.  Aroma is caramel malt forward followed by dried fruit, coffee, breadlike notes and sour munich malt.  Appearance is medium brown, clean, with a medium off-white head.  Flavor is sour bready malt forward with very light sweetness, roast character, nuttiness, with low bittering and no hop character.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with light cream and a very dry finish.  Overall, clean with a lot of complicated bready notes.
pours a really nice dark amber. creamy, with foamy head and light lacing.  roasted malt on the nose.  sweet malty flavor. slight hop finish

Bottle. Beautiful burgundy amber color. Nice looking full head with mild lacing. Aroma of toasted crystal malt. Clean simple caramel flavors dominate. Subtle hop notes balance the maltiness. Excellent and smooth drinking beer.
500 ml bottle. Mug. Mahogany with a decent tan head. Aroma of malt and cocoa. Taste has notes of coffee, dark chocolate and roast malt. It was a bit thin and watery for my taste though.

500mL bottle.  Pours a clear, cherry cola color; off-white head with decent lacing.  Plenty of dried cherries and fresh malts in the aroma; syrupy and dense.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: dense dried fruits, caramel, and nougat; intense chewy maltiness that manages to (somehow) seem balanced and drinkable without any prominent show of bitterness; really tasty.  Lengthy, chocolate and toasted malt finish, with the slightest show of citrus bitterness.

Bottle sampled. Pours a bronze color with a small white head. Aroma of toasted grain, roasted malts and sweet barley. Flavor was very refreshing with hazelnut, caramel, honey, and some dark fruits with a light bitterness finish. A very good dunkel.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2012 Re-rate, 5/2012 - on draft at Aying, original rating was pretty darned spot on. Even better on draft. A great example of the style. Maybe worth a tick or two up, but Im too lazy. Original rating: Well, the last three dunkels Ive had are all good stuff, this at the top, probably THE top of all dunkels tasted by me. Appearance was clear coppery brown, nice two finger head, great retention, solid lacing. The aroma was bread, light earthiness, nuts, some roast. The flavor was firm and pleasing nuts, roasted malts, coffee, finishing with a touch of bready/earthy/slightly grassy dryness. Some fruity tones appear on the tongue after the dry roasted nuts and coffee leave, but not firmly so. The mouthfeel was moderate for the style. A dunkel rich in flavor, depth like a schwarz, but lighter and more drinkable as a dunkel. Nice stuff, Aying.
Beer 69 Summer 2006 trip in Europe.  Drank on 711/06 on tap @ Ayinger in the Brew pub room.  Very nice smooth finishing dunkel probably one of the best Dunkels I had on the trip.

Dark brown with a nice 2 finger white head. Nice carbonation. Has a lot of dark fruit and malt but the sweetness is kept in line by the bubbles. Some Sugar Daddy in the background and a little bitterness in the aftertaste. I love Ayinger beers even though I cant pronounce most of them.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 Bottle on 05/01/2011. Clear dark amber body with a medium creamy off-white head. Sweet toasty and bready malt aroma with some caramel. Sweet caramel and toasty, bready malt flavor. Medium body with moderate carbonation. 7/4/7/3/14 - 3.5 

On 06/08/2007. Clear ruby body with a medium creamy light brown head. Sweet light molassas aroma. Sweet molassas flavor with a nutty background. 7/4/7/3/13 - 3.4

Pour is a dark brown with a white head.  Aroma is very nice with hints of nuts and roasted malts.  Flavor is excellent.  Lots of dark fruits(plum and dates) with some toffee and sweet caramel.  Wow a good example of this style and one that is quite affordable.

500mL as pictured.  Amber pour with some red colors as the light hit it.  One-finger white head that bubbled actively and diminished fairly quickly.  Scent of sweet malt, raisin, caramel, toffee, banana and other fruits.  Roastier on the taste, with very little bitterness and a sweet cream finish.  Crisp clean aftertaste.  Enjoyable indeed.
Bronze with no carbonation. Bronze appearance and pleasant enough to drink. No better than slightly above average but still one I would try again.

Wonderful dark color, sweetish malty aroma backed with some hops. Flavor is as good as Ive ever had in a dark lager of its strength. Caramelly, roatsty, and slightly sweet, but never cloying. A winner.

Red brown pour with an off white creamy head.  Nose of toffee, vanilla, plum, oak...very nice.  Flavor is bready, fairly smooth on the palate, slight smokiness and dark roast as well.  Easy to taste.  The finish is a little thin, otherwise this is a pretty darn good brew here.

Quite possibly, nothing here is going to rock your world, but the execution/brewing is near-flawless.  Perhaps a touch too much on the carbonation, and the finish could stand to be more biting for a lager, but the overall attenuation is well-done, and the flavors are quite elegant.
