16.9oz - Aroma of toasted malts and sprouts.  A little nutty.  Pours transparent red-brown with medium head and good lacing.  Flavor is toasty, earty, malty, with barley, sprouts, and nuts.  Palate is kind of thin and sticky.  Not bad

Brown with clear red shine, big bubbled head stays long, leaves laces; Huge nose, deep, first loads of grapefruit (like the carbonation blows in your face), later notes of soil, dark baked white bread, loads of character; Quite bitter/ acidy body, a bit to the watery thin side; Long but again watery thin finish that has a chewy bitterness and the same aroma as the nose. I find that the character of nose and body isnt all that coherent.

(bottle, with many thanks to joss!) Clear dark ruby brown colour with a stable foamy beige head. Sweet toasted malt aroma with caramel, chocolate and herbal hops. Sweetbitter flavour, medium body, very smooth mouthfeel. Sweet toastmalty taste with caramel and herbal hops; medium dry lingering toasty and hopbitter finish with a lasting aftertaste.
Tasty, with a hint of spice. Pours a golden-brown with good head. Finish was okay, but not as long or good as I was hoping.

Bottle (best regard to joss): Dark amber coloured with red sparks, small, stable beige head; stronger aroma of roasted malt with a touch of coffee (almost a smoked aroma); slightly sweetish flavour with some bitterness in the wings; slightly sweetish, but later dry "roasted" malty and bitter finish. A light bodied goodie.........
Brown pour wiht huge head boiling over the glass.  Dark fruit, roast malt aroma.  Weird smokiness to the flavor that I didnt enjoy, long lingering finish.  Stronger flavor than I expected.
Draught at Speis und Trank. Red brownish colour with a medium modly lasting light brown head. Powerful taste and aroma of malts, hobs and caramel. Great beer.
Draught at Speis und Trank. Creamy off-white mostly lasting head. Red-brown colour. Powerfull hoppy and malty aroma. Very caramellic average finish. Alittle watery but still nice. A very good beer.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2007 Pours a nice brown color with a large fizzy head that diminishes quickly. Has an aroma of sweet malts, coffee and caramel. Flavor is malty. Slight smokiness to it along with caramel and dark fruits. The mouth is fairly thin and fizzy but refreshing as well. Pretty good.

500 ml bottle.  Pours a dark ruby brown with a smallish foamy head.  Aromas are very malty.  Sour malts with some yeastiness too.  Prunes too.  Smoke was the first thing I got on the flavor.  But it was minimal.  Very roasty malty flavor.  More dark fruits.  A touch of spiciness on the finish and a bit of dust.  Very good

500ml bottle poured a clear brown with a lasting amber head. Aromas of plum, bakers chocolate, and a slight hint of coffee. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of bakers chocolate, mild coffee, and some fruitiness with a smooth finish.
Pours dark brown. Nose of dark roasted coffee and wet hay. Medium sized froth/hangtime. Nice effers. Flavors of cocoa, coffee, malted leather. Finishes dry. Overall: Not my favorite Dunkle.

500ml on tap at a friendly and cosy pub in Turku, Finland called Uusi Apteekki. Recommended by the staff. A dark lager, opaque dark brown on colour. Warming aroma. Slightly carbonated. Malty start and notes of black coffee in the finish (02.03.2006).

I had this poured from the bottle with a pork with apples meal. Its sweetness mixed well with the pork, especially where it was crispy. As a palate cleanser, the snappy carbonation worked well, but it isnt a beer Id drink by itself.

We took the kids to the Nine Inch Nails show in Cincy Saturday night.  On the way down
we stopped at Mecklenburg Gardens.  I had one of these from a bottle before dinner. 
Nose of butterscotch and brown sugar.  Pours a clear ruby copper.  The tall creamy tan
rocky head is mostly lasting with no lace.  The flavor is somewhat shallow, but is fresh and
pleasant.  The floral finish has a bready caramel quality.  The light to medium body is
creamy and soft.  Im not one for malty styles, but this brew worked well with my meal.  I
recommend the Hungarian Goulash.  Hats off to the owners of this fine establishment, we
all left very happy.
Bottle.  Smooth, easy drinkin goodness, sessie to the core.  Earthy fruit, berry hoery dark forest flavor.  Bark lager.  Good.

Pours a clear rather dark brown with reddish hues.  The head is tan and bubbly evaporating leisurely to leave a quarter inch head.  The aroma is very sweat and caramely, rich.  It is a very nicely sweet caramel and chocolate malts on the tongue with a gentle lingering bittterness of dark chocolate and I still sense caramel.  Rich and thick in the mouth with a playful tingle this is very nice.
Nice caramely tasting beer, malty caramel smell, translucent dark brown color, really tasty and drinkable with plenty of caramel malt flavor.
Dunkeltastical.  Dark roasted color and taste.  One of the better dunkels Ive had.
Beautiful dark caramel color. Wonderful earthy-chocolately-caramely taste. Not very sweet, but also not bitter. Highly recommended.

500 mL bottle.  Pours mahagony with a medium tan frothy head that lasts a while.  Aroma is yeast (barn, earth) and caramel malt (grain, meal) and maple.  Malty, yeasty flavor, low sweetness , no bitterness, acidity.  Medium bodied and smooth, light fizzy palate.

Outstanding example of Munich Dunkel. This beer pours to a beautiful, bright, deep chestnut color with a nice white head, and a good bit of carbonation. The nose on this beer is excellent with lots of good aromas of sweet malt, light toast and nuts. The palate is round and clean with lots of good sweet malt, toast and nutty malt flavor. This beer finishes with more good malt character then ends with enough herbal hop bittereness to round this one out to perfection. A great match to hearty German fare, and BBQ dishes.

Very nice. Pours a dark brown with a nice thick dense head. Aromas of dark malt, yeast, and a slight smoke flavor.A fresh yeast taste with an underlying smokey flavor. This would be a great session beer.

Clear brown body with light tan head. Aroma filled with malts, both sweet and toasted. The flavor has notes of bread, toffee and sweet fruits. Youll notice a bitterness, but only if youre paying attention. Medium to thin body  a little too thin. Smooth, refreshing.
sweet and spicy aroma of malted barley and licorice. orange  ruby color.  small off-white head.  medium bodied. mild.  sticky.  sweet caramel and toffee.  plum finish.

Cranberry brown pour.  Lots of fresh cherry juice in the aroma and body.  The body is a bit thin, but filled with notes of chocolate, vanilla, roasted beans and more fruit.  Finishes watery.  Good, but I want more of everything to make this great.

(500 ml bottle) Clear medium brown, soft pillowy biscuit head. Nose of sweet maltiness, hay, brown sugar, caramel. Good lacing. Silky mouthfeel. Tastes of fine malty sweetness, some smokiness. Mildly bitter finish. Great.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2006 From the bottle
Froths up into a big tan head in the stein; the aroma is molassas and plum, with a bit of leather and yeast and humus. As the beer warms, it takes on a strong,unmistakable, and curious if not as unpleasant-as-it-might-sound scent of agar. The flavor is not as sweet as Id expected, with smoky malt, bittersweet burnt sugar, hints of peat and corkboard. Despite adequate carbonation, the mouthfeel is a bit thin and round rather than crisp; the finish provides a bit of smoke-and-hops bitterness.

This is a reasonably good beer, but not a standout like Ayingers Celebrator.

500 mL brown bottle served at Osteria del Stato restaurant, Chicago, IL.  Clear dark brown ale having a long-lasting creamy off-white head with good lacing. Spicy sweet malt aroma. No discernable carbonation.  Medium bodied that starts with light sweet malt, spice and caramel flavors.  Finishes with light sweet malt aftertaste. No discernable bitterness.  Went well with my roast chicken lunch.  This is a very good drinkable malty session beer.
Pours a deep dark brown.  Aromas of roasted malts, smoke, and hints of fruit.  Flavors of the roasted malts, some fruit, with a coffee aftertaste.

Appears copper with aubunr trim. Even layer of head across the glass. Aroma is alt caramel, and malt grain. Texture is pure and refined and is easily drunk.  The malt has a very light sweet taste with mre flavor siding towards caramel most of all.

Bottled. Chocolat malts and caramel aroma. Brown color, beige head, good lace. Light sweet, dark caramel flavor, light bitter, chocolat in the finish, light herbal, light nutty. Medium body and light dry in the finish. Like a lighter version of the Celebrator.
Poured with a thick, lasting head and a deep coffee color.  Tasted of molasses and as the description said, plums.  The beer was highly enjoyable, and finished without a bitter finish.
Dark amber in color with a small off-white head. Slightly bitter, could be a little maltier. Thick mouthfeel.

Bottle (500ml). Poured glowing clear deep mahogany with a small off-white head.  Its a mild nose, but theres peaty malt, some darker fruits, a bit raisiny.  Taste is syrupy dark fruits and roast malt, theres a bit of chocolate and plum in there, again a slight earthiness, but this finishes like a dry white wine, not as long or malty a finish as other dunkels Ive had.  Very pleasant, Id drink it again.

Excellent beer. Rich amber color. Off white head. Nose is full of tomatoes. Dusty malts. Nice simple sweetness. Slight raisin. Flavors are powerful. Deep rich slight roastiness is primary. Slight ketchup on the edges. Tart and sweet all at once. Murky dryness in the finish. Kepps going. Carbonated evenly. This beer is excellent.

(Bottle 50 cl) Dark brown, clear beer with a light brownish head. Lovely malty character with some light caramel- and toffee notes. Very clasical for its style, but a bit too heavily carbonated. 010502
White Medium head with brownish light color.  Malted taste with a little coffee.

This was a great beer.  Dark redish color woth a smooth creamy head.  Malty sweet rich dark character.  Hops are not present as to style.  Medium mouthfeel clean easy drinking beer and I want another.  I make this out to be the snickers of all beers.  It has al the great flavors chcolate and carlmel mixed.

Pours a very dark amber body. Aroma is earthy and chocolately but also caramel. Flavor is the same. Finishes extremely smooth, but almost feels watery. It avoids it because theres complexity here. Good stuff.

Big tan, creamy head over beautifully dark red/purple body. Aroma of very sweet malts, with notes of syrup and hay. Nice. The taste is again very sweet and malty, but is soon dominated by a smoky hay-like flavour, which lingers and fades. Subtle, yet complex, and very
interesting. An excellent lager!

(0.5l bottle in glass.)

The color is a very clear red/mohogany with a big off-white head. The aroma is dominated my malt, with toffee and roasty overtones. The tatse is similar, but has some chocolate a fruity tones as well. It still finsihes relatively dry with some nuttiness and bitterness in the aftertaste.
A better Dunkel than any of the other I have tried. Malty with coffe overtones.  I guess Im just not a Dunkel kind of beer taster. They dont make me want to finish the glass.

Pours ruby red with a generous off tan head that laces the glass nicely throughout the sampling.  Aromas of caramel, brown sugar, and pepper radiate from this one initially.  As the beer settles, some nice mellow clove like qualities emerge.  Taste is of roses, cherries, and some tangy oranges.  As the beer warms up, some nice chocolatey nutty notes begin to emerge.  Finish is grassey and a bit bitter but not overwhelming.  Full tingy mouthfeel.
Bottle.  pours a clean, deep brown color.  Smells of caramel malts.  Real clean mouthfeel, lots of malty flavors and hints of chocolate and fruit.  A bit nutty.

500mL bottle.  Label is slightly different than that in the picture.  A clear ruby pour with a smallish, bubbly tan head.  Aroma of dark malts, chocolate, grapes and soy sauce.  Medium body.  Lots of malts in the taste.  Hints of chocolate and coffee.  A little bit of grapes and nuts too.  A dry, coffee-esque bitter finish.
Poured a beautiful brown, No real head to speak of but lacing lasted. Malty slightest bit of smoke. Smooth malty taste sweet with a little to much fizz. But most enjoyable will try again.
Very beautiful beer.  Full and round and just nice.  Long lingering aftertaste of almonds and toffee.  Enjoyable and drinkable.
Poured a nice brown, a bit smokey, didnt seem too sweet for me, actually had a very good flavor. I liked this one qiute abit, Another good brew from Ayinger!

Pours a lush brown with a nice head of foam.  Aroma is 99% molasses, and that doesnt sit very well with me.  Flavor is molasses, roasted malt, and faint hops.  A bit watered down in the palate.  It needs a more vibrant flavor to push it over the top towards being a great beer.  Otherwise, its status quo.  Still, not a bad beer; just could be a lot better.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: pours a brownish color, with a small tan compact head, aromas of fruit, raosted malts and sweetness, the taste is dry and bitter, cofee-like, not bad, just not my thing.
Semi-sweet and dry, flavor is of malt, coffee and raisins with a smoky undertone.  A little weak on the overall flavor, but that might be due to the beer I just had.  Try again & re-rate.

Malty aroma, vegetably. Reminds me a bit of chicken broth or cheap gravy and mashed potatoes. Pour was a deepish yellow/brown, with a decent head and no lacing. Flavor was big on vegetables... if I actually ate mine, I may be able to identify which ones :) A bit of maltiness as well but an overly watery palate doesnt allow much flavor to come through.

Reddish-brownish, slightly hazy, with a dense light brown head. Really nice aroma  kind of a pumpernickel bread along with some sweetish, fruity notes. Flavor is nocely toasty, with hints of raisin. Slightly peppery, smoky finish.
Easy to rate.  Simply may very well be the best Dunkel out there.  See the commercial description and the good ratings.  Then imagine the beer is actually better.  Taste.  Affirm.

Bottle: Reddish copper, translucent, large foamy light beige head, nice lacing, but virtually no carbonation. &nbsp Dark bready aroma, slight fig or date. &nbsp Toasted malt on the tongue with a definite smokey aspect to it. &nbsp The smoke aspect, or charred wood, is stronger here than in any other Dunkel I have had to date. &nbsp Fairly big bodied with a moderate mouthfeel. &nbsp Malty finish, not as bready as on the nose, with lingering charred wood. &nbsp Good, but a little unexpected.

From a bottle at The Bavarian Inn in Shepherdstown, WV. Served cold in a quasi-wheat beer glass. Pours dark brown with a creamy light brown head. Medium lacing. Light aroma of dark maltscaramel, chocolate, and coffee. Flavor matches the aroma, but with added dark fruits. Very subtle. Not a beer that blows you away, but one that is clearly well-made and true to its style. Went well with wiener schnitzel and cabbage. I found the carbonation to be excessive.
See-through brown. Like the Ur-weisse, it has both light and heavy moments. A redrinkable beer for sure, reminds me of Michelob amber bock but better.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2007 Deep brown and copper color, clear, decent head.  Aroma is very much malt oriented, with a tinge of sourness.  Thick in the mouth, flavors are those of liquid malt extract and slightly burnt caramel.  Not bad, but the fruitiness seems to express itself more as a slightly off sour note in this bottle.  RERATE:  tasted as part of a BJCP training session.  The malts in the nose expressed themselves basically as cat food.  Odd, but correct.  Faint raisin, lots of malt.  Abrupt finish.  Bumped up aroma by 1 point, other marks stay the same.

Vrey attractive glassy red amber color with a thich foam head.  The aroma is strong of malt sweet characters, some fruit and alcohol.  I would have expected this to be higher than 5%.  There is a lot of caramel and roasted scent to this, as well as a bit of cherry.  Flavor falls off a bit in my opinion.  Some metallic tastes come through a heafty malt body.  THe palate however is pretty enjoyable, smooth all around.  A good malt and fruit blend makes for one tastey beer.
Dark amber with a rocky tan head.  Pine hop aroma mixed with molasses.  Toasted malty taste with coffee notes. Oily texture.  Light bitter aftertaste, slight dry lager finish.
Pours a nutty brown boardering on amber when held up to the light, nice tan head. A nice roasted malt aroma. Bittersweet and smooth taste with a fruity finish.

bottle.  medium colored brown ( I can see light through my glass )  with a nice looking tan head.  commercial description is dead on!  roasted malt, plums, toffee and just a hint of coffee.  a very nice and well done dunkel.
Very solid dunkel, but slightly astringent... almost sour.  Not as malty as I would have liked after comparing it to the Kulmbacher

Bottled. Roastmalty, slightly coffeish with cocoa-like notes. Dry hop-bitter, roastmalty taste. Coffeish notes. Ends quite dry. Full body for the style with a smooth mouthfeel. Would love to have this on tap, as it is a little behind the best Czech dunkels I had fresh from tap. Great stuff.

Poured a rich reddish-brown color producing a 1/2 inch thick head of rapidly dissipating foam. The aroma is incredible. The nose was of fresh, dark roasted malts with a hint of cocoa. The taste started with rich roasted malts, hazelnut and a hint of molasses. Hops come next nicely balancing the malt sweetness carring it through to the end. A subtle sting of espresso in the finish leave s you with the perfect mixture of sweetness and bitterness. The feel was light-medium bodied, yet creamy. This might be the best of the non-Doppelbock German beers I have sampled. This beer is fantastic and I strongly recomend this one.
Bottle. Brown amber hue with small head. Strong malt and caramel aroma. Medium body with small bitter finish. Good brew to style.
bottled, brown color.  mild aroma of malt, medium bodied.  the flavor is subdued, w/ hint of coffee and caramel. crispy finish.
Deep beautiful mahogany pour and a dense light brown head of foam. Big aroma of malt and caramel, flavors all malt with a little hops. Almost syrupy sticky and sweet. Love it.

Pours a deep rich cherrywood color with a dense creamy light brown head. Smells of rich malt and caramel. Bready.

Taste is the same as the nose. Bready and really malty. Some light finishing hops. Lightly sour. Rich caramel and fruity. Mouth is sweet and lightly sticky. Pretty tasty dunkel.

Pours a clear deep orange-red with a dense and lasting head. Aromas of malt, malt and more malt. The flavor is smooth, with almost a touch of sour-fruitiness but a distracting metallic flavor in the finish. We shall see if this dissipates as I continue. Smooth and "drinkable" which sometimes means uninteresting, but here this is a well made beer that aims for a smooth, dark malt experience. I dont notice that metallic flavor anymore- what is that? I have noticed it in beers before and I dont like it.

Where oh where have you gone, my old friend? Used to be widely available in Louisiana and Texas, but now nowhere to be seen. My favorite beer of all time. Great malt body, with just the right amount of hops. Full flavor and great head retention. Although it is heavy and sweet, I could drink this till I popped.

Couleur brune foncée allant vers le cuivrée.  Poussière de grains résidant en permanence dans lécurie, biscuits et céréales.  Flaveurs de grains, caramel et toffee.  Corps dépaisseur moyenne, quelque peu vineuse et fruitée  en bouche.  Typiquement allemand!  Brattleboro, 22 Mai 2005.

500 ml bottle.  No date, but there is a touch of oxidation.  Brown and garnet with a nice tan cap on top.  Strong malt nose featuring chocolate, and toffee.  No hops here.  Buttery chocolate with a drying at the end.  Light carb is nice.  Well worth the coupole of bucks fo the bottle.

Pours deep copper with medium off-white head and big carbonation bubbles.  Aroma is caramel malt, hopcit, dark fruit, hops, nuts.  Tastes very caramelly, withy some figgy and nutty and toffee elements at mid palate and at the finish.  The finale gets extremely caramelly, perhaps moreso than any other beer Ive ever had.  This beer is very complex and well balanced, and as with other Ayinger beers, it is exceptional in quality.

Burgundy color.  Light malt nose with hints of plums and berries, along with caramel.  Its quite dry as well.  Palate is round and complex, smoky, and full of rich malt flavors (caramel, toffee, fruit) along with hints of vanilla.  Creamy mouthfeel, yet slightly watery texture.

Very dark amber color, almost brown.  The head was a slight tan frothy, creamy one.  Great taste, very smooth with an a hint of caramel in the taste.  Slightly roasty nose and taste.  Very good I would try this again anyday.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2006 Rich caramel aroma. Really quite sweet in terms of initial flavors. Dense, bready malts with some chocolate and a bit of coffee and smoke towards the finish. Great stuff, one of my favorite brews from Ayinger.

Aroma was of malts and licorice. Dark amber body with small head that settled to a thin layer on top of beer. Cherry fruit flavor that was also rich. Left fruty aftertaste on the palate which was good. Decent beer.
Tap at Ayinger bräuhaus München. Dark red brown colour with a medium off-white head. Light sweet malty nutty aroma and a sweet caramel nutty taste. Medium body and a sweet light dry finish.

Very clear rustic orangey-brown color with a beautiful spongey medium sized cap of densely built, organic egg shell colored froth. Settles down to a firm skim with some buttery bubbles. Lacing coats well in strings.

Aroma has a well rounded nuttyness to it backed by some fresh baked wheat bread that has a slight toasty edge. Clean and inviting with a peculiar softness to its waft that grows a bit in strength as it warms.

Taste is easy goin and clean with a nice softness to its overall character thats enticingly unique yet very Ayinger-like. Something about the combo of flavors and carbonation makes for a very pleasant experience bringing a nutty wheat bread grain that sits remarkably clean and well rounded. Fluffy and delicate in nature, yet just enough boldness in the flavors to raise the eyebrows more then once. Notes of dusted cocoa and smokeyish sweet malt play with touches of caramel. Bread tones dominate taste, form, and function with this one though.

Feel is wonderfully soft and bready, warm bready is more like it; great, delicately precise carbonation with a semi-light chewyness to its bready nature.

I liked everything about this beer. Its not a brute by any means in huge amounts of aroma and flavor. But whats there sets perfectly for what it is, its very natural tasting and feeling. The bread tones in all its characteristics are just right. A fantastic brew and sessionable to boot. Love those Munich malts! Mmmm...fresh breads...
Dark amber  with a bug head that settled pretty quickly. Awesome aroma of Munich malts and chocolate. The syrupy body is full of rich tastes (mostly sweet). Could use some more hoppiness.

In the 0.5L bottle at the Huber Haus. Pours a very dark brown color with a vividly white foamy head. Aroma is a roasted coffee-like smell. This dunkel is medium in body for the style with a great roasted malt flavor. Has that slightly medicine-like taste of an Alt. Very good.

500ml bottle.  Beautiful pour...thick rocky head, frantic craze of carbonation, beauty of a wooden brown color.  Smells nice & malty w/ a light mix of fruit and nuts...Malty, nutty flavor is smooth & slightly sweet...body is light, making for a very tasty session beer.  I think Ayinger might be one of my favorite German breweries.

Clear, mahogany body with a large, tan head that fades to a film but leaves a fat lace. Aroma as described by brewer: sweetly malted... with licorice, grapes and earth. Watery, indistinct malt taste to start, leading to red wine and smoke... couldnt find the coffee, but I did get a taste of plums afterwards. Overall, rather thin and unassuming.
